runninghead.i: Chapter 71 Cardinaletti and Giusti: Syntax of Quantified Phrases
Chapter 71 Cardinaletti and Giusti: Syntax of Quantified Phrases

titlegroup.title: 71 The Syntax of Quantified Phrases and Quantitative Clitics

li.p: The first element of the partitive construction
The functional structure of quantified noun phrases
A refinement of the QP Hypothesis
The partitive PP and other partitive phrases
A bare phrase structure for QP
The lexical non-distinctness requirement on DP and PP
On the nature of the maximal projection bound by quantitative clitics

subsection.heading: 1 Introduction
subsection.p: Quantifiers and other expressions of quantity can appear in a wide range of different constructions. In this case, we focus on constructions containing existential quantifiers, namely, cardinals and so-called ‘vague numerals’ such as many, few, and some, because they are the ones that appear with quantitative clitic pronouns (such as French en). Other quantifiers, such as universal all and both, and distributive every and each, are treated only when relevant to the discussion. Other quantity expressions including semi-lexical elements such as lot in a lot of people, measure nouns such as bottle in a bottle of wine, and the like also co-occur with quantitative clitic pronouns but are not treated here for reasons of space. 1

The problems raised by constructions containing a quantifier are of different natures. We cluster them into three main issues: the headedness of the quantified phrase, the status of the partitive PP often co-occurring with it, and the analysis of clitic pronouns such as French en, Italian ne, Dutch er, and Czech jich, which can bind (part of) a quantitative phrase.

Since quantified phrases constitute a special kind of noun phrase, it is important to establish whether they are noun phrases in the technical sense (DPs in current terms) or the projection of a different category. In this respect it must be decided whether the quantifier in all or some of the constructions in (1) is a modifier of the following noun or whether it is the head of the construction:

(1)
a. three/many boys
b. all/both boys
c. some boys
d. each boy
If we insert a ‘determiner’, such as an article, a demonstrative, or a possessive in (1), we obtain different results with different quantifiers, as shown in (2–5):

(2)
a. the/these/his three boys a′. the/these/his many boys
b. *three the/these/his boys b′. *many the/these/his boys

(3)
a. *the/*these/*his all boys a′. *the/*these/*his both boys
b. all the/these/his boys b′. both (*the)/these/his boys

(4)
a. *the/*these/*his some boys
b. *some the/these/his boys

(5)
a. *the/*these/*his each boy
b. *each these/his boys

From the results in (2–5), we could roughly divide quantifiers into three groups: (i) quantifiers that can be preceded but not followed by a determiner, such as three and many in (2); (ii) quantifiers that can or must be followed by a determiner, such as all and both in (3); and (iii) quantifiers that can never co-occur with any determiner, such as some in (4) and each in (5).

The basic question is whether it is more correct to unify the structural positions in which one and the same quantity expression can appear in (1) and (2–5) and try to derive the different word orders arising in the presence of a determiner, from different properties of each quantifier, or whether it is more correct to propose that the quantity expressions in (1) are in one and the same structural position while they occupy different positions in (2–5). This latter option would have the result that lexical items, such as three and many in (1a) and (2a, a′), would be analyzed as occurring in different structural positions, while (1b) could be unified with (3b, b′).
Quantifiers can also co-occur with a ‘partitive PP’ introduced by of:

(6)
a. three/many of the boys
b. all/both of the boys
c. some of the boys
d. each of the boys

In the late 1960s and 1970s, the debate was primarily concerned with the question as to whether constructions such as those in (1) and (6) are derived from one and the same structure or not. In the early 1980s, the research on the functional structure of noun phrases re-opened a number of issues in this field of inquiry.

The third question concerns the nature of the clitic pronouns found in co-occurrence with certain quantifiers in Romance (French, Italian, Catalan), Germanic (Dutch), and Slavic (Czech, Slovak, Serbian–Croatian, etc.). Here, the main problem is to establish whether the source of (7a) is (7b) or (7c), in other words, whether the ‘quantitative clitic’ en in (7a) resumes the indefinite noun garçons in (7b), the partitive PP de ces garçons in (7c), or even a different constituent.

(7)
a. J’ en ai vu deux.
I EN have seen two
b. J’
ai vu deux garçons.
I
have seen two boys
c. J’
ai vu deux
de ces garçons.
I
have seen two
of these boys

This chapter is organized as follows. In section 2 we see the different logical options that arise in relation to the internal structure of quantified phrases and how it has been addressed in the literature. Section 3 presents a development of the proposal presented in Cardinaletti and Giusti (1992). In section 4 we turn to quantitative clitics.

subsection.heading: 2 The structure of quantified constructions
subsection.p: Among the many issues that arise on the structure of the noun phrases in (1–6), we first want to address some questions related to the categorial status of quantified phrases. The literature on this has often treated the questions in (8) as tightly related to each other:

(8)
a. What is the head of a nominal construction containing a quantifier such as those in (1–6)?
b. What is the categorial status and the structural position of the quantifier in each of (1–6)?
c. Is there a difference in categorial status and/or structural position between
i a quantifier that is neither preceded nor followed by a determiner as in (1);
ii a quantifier preceded by a determiner as in (2a, a′);
iii. a quantifier followed by a determiner as in (3b, b′)?
d. Is there a syntactic relation between (1) and (6), and if so of what kind?
We show that while (8a) and (8b) are conceptually related, (8c) and (8d) are independent from the others.
In principle, question (8a) has two possible answers, namely, those in (9):

(9)
a. The head of the quantified noun phrase is the noun.
b. The head of the quantified noun phrase is the quantifier.

The literature up to the late 1980s did not distinguish between lexical and functional categories. In that framework, the quantity expression is taken to be either a modifier of the noun (determiner or adjective) or something external to the noun phrase (namely, a full noun phrase itself). In sections 2.1–2.2 we review the major issues in the literature of the 1970s and 1980s.

In the last decade, the discussion on the lexical–functional distinction opens up a new way of looking at the matter, so that question (8b), concerning the categorial status of quantifiers, enters into play. In this perspective, (9b) divides into the two possibilities in (10):

(10)
a. The quantifier is a functional head of the noun phrase.
b. The quantifier is an autonomous lexical head embedding the noun phrase.

In other words, it is logically possible both that the quantifier is a functional head and that it is a lexical head embedding the noun phrase as its complement. This issue is discussed in sections 2.3 and 3.
Quite independently of its head or maximal status, the question arises as to the merging point of the quantifier. In this respect three alternatives arise:

(11)
a. The quantifier is merged higher than D.
b. The quantifier is merged lower than D.
c. The quantifier is merged in D.

In sections 2.3 and 3 we show that there is no simple answer to (8c) and that the word orders arising with the combination of quantifiers and determiners are epiphenomenal and must be explained by the independent interaction of general UG properties with the categorial status that each language assigns to lexical items expressing quantity. None of the choices in (9–11) entails a straightforward answer for (8c), which must be treated separately, although interacting with one of the two lines of analysis proposed above. Here the possibilities grow exponentially, and it would be puzzling to consider them in detail here. Every proposal that we consider in this chapter treats this question one way or the other. Finally, any of the choices above can interact with the three possible answers to question (8d) given in (12):

(12)
a. The of PP in (6) has the same status as the bare noun appearing with the same quantifiers in (1).
b. Both the of PP in (6) and the bare noun in (1) can appear with the quantifier and are inserted at different merging points.
c. Both the of PP in (6) and the bare noun in (1) can appear with the quantifier and are in complementary distribution.

The question in (8d) has been the focus of the literature in the 1970s. Unfortunately, the in-depth insights that this literature had reached by the end of that decade has been neglected by the subsequent work, which often made unmotivated assumptions on this issue.

In the course of the last four decades of studies in generative grammar, almost all the possibilities mentioned in (8–12) have been explored. We present some of what we consider the most significant proposals on these issues chronologically, highlighting the empirical advantages and drawbacks of each in turn. In section 2.1 we consider proposals formulated in the Extended Standard Theory (EST). In section 2.2 we briefly observe the advance of the theory in the GB framework. In section 2.3 we present some proposals that are formulated in the more recent framework of the functional structure of noun phrases.

subsection.heading: 2.1 EST proposals
subsection.p: In the 1960s and 1970s, phrase-structure rules did not distinguish between adjectives and so-called ‘determiners’ such as demonstratives and quantifiers. All of them were considered maximal elements in Specifier positions, adjoined to Nn levels according to the linear order in which they appear in expressions.

The first proposals about the syntax of quantified noun phrases address the question whether it is possible to derive simple quantified noun phrases such as those in (1) and quantified noun phrases containing a partitive PP such as (6) from one and the same deep structure. Jackendoff (1968) motivates the generally held hypothesis that there is a common deep structure for (1) and (6), later found as granted in Chomsky (1970: 200). Following later work by Selkirk (1977), we call this line of reasoning the Hidden Partitive Hypothesis (HPH). A decade later, this hypothesis is successfully challenged by Selkirk (1977) and clearly abandoned by Jackendoff (1977) himself in favor of the Simple Noun Phrase Hypothesis (SH). At the same time, Milner (1978b) dedicates an in-depth study to these constructions in French. The properties of French, in particular the partitive article des, which can occur in the absence of a quantity expression, and the quantitative clitic en, allow him to give motivated answers to most of the questions mentioned in (8–12). For reasons of space, we are able to reproduce only very few of Milner's arguments on these issues, and refer the interested reader to his monograph.

subsection.heading: 2.1.1 The Hidden Partitive Hypothesis (HPH)
subsection.p: The main aim of Jackendoff (1968) is to offer an alternative to previous proposals according to which quantified noun phrases derive from quite different deep structures. One proposal, attributed by Jackendoff to Chomsky, elaborated by Partee (1962), and given without discussion in Chomsky (1970: 200), considered some of the as a structured Det, thereby losing the constituency of the PP of the men. A second proposal, attributed by Jackendoff to Postal and elaborated by Dean (1966), derived some of the men from a complex NP some men of the men with deletion of the first instance of men. (We turn to a similar proposal in section 3.) A third proposal, elaborated in the framework of generative semantics by Lakoff (1965) and Carden (1967), considered the construction as derived from a relative clause whose predicate was the quantifier.

Jackendoff (1968) divides quantity expressions into three groups. Group I contains nouns expressing quantity, such as a group, a herd, and a wagonload; group II contains quantifiers such as some, each, few, all, both, and also which; group III includes only cardinals and so-called (vague) numerals such as a few, many, one, and three. The three groups have in common that the partitive PP co-occurring with the quantity expression must contain a mass or a plural noun phrase (13), and that it cannot be quantified itself (14):

(13)
a. *a group of the man
b. *each of the garbage can
c. *three of the book

(14)
a. *a group of some men
b. *some of all the men
c. *one of few of the beetles

Jackendoff further points out that the quantity expressions in groups I and III can be preceded by an article (15a, c), while those in group II cannot (15b), and notices a restriction on definite articles that can only appear once in the construction, unless the noun phrase embedded in the PP contains a relative clause (16–17):

(15)
a. the group(s) of men
b. *the some men
c. the three men

(16)
a. the group of men
b. a group of the men
c. *the group of the men
d. the group of the men that had already left

(17)
a. the three men
b. three of the men
c. *the three of the men
d. the three of the men you met yesterday

The structural analysis in (18–20) captures the similarities among the three groups by assuming nominal status for all three kinds of quantity expression. The differences between group I (18) and group III (20), on the one hand, and group II (19), on the other hand, is captured by proposing that group II quantifiers are Det and N at the same time, since they do not co-occur with articles and, at the same time, entertain a grammatical relation with the following PP.

Supporting evidence for the N-status of group I quantifiers in (18) is that they are also used as common nouns. The N-status is extended to group III quantifiers in (20) without much motivation. The fact that group III quantifiers do not co-occur with adjectives (cf. *the good three of the men) is not considered counter-evidence for their N-status since even group I nouns do not occur with adjectives in their quantifying use:

(21)
a. a big group of men comes/*come every day
b. a group of men comes/come every day

In (21a) the quantity noun group is modified by an adjective. In this case the only possibility for it is to function as a regular N with a complement (of men), triggering singular agreement on the verb. If a noun like group is not modified by an adjective, as in (21b), it can either function as a regular noun, as in (21a), or be considered a quantity expression. In this latter case, agreement on the verb is triggered by the plural noun men, which in this case is the head of the construction. Finally, Jackendoff (1968: 428) proposes an of-deletion transformation for groups II and III in order to attribute structures (19–20) also to the cases where no overt preposition appears, as in some men and three men. This transformation does not apply to group I.

subsection.heading: 2.1.2 The Simple Noun Phrase Hypothesis (SH)
subsection.p: Selkirk (1977) shows that simple quantified constructions and those embedding a partitive phrase are different and that the latter cannot be transformationally derived from the former. She argues in favor of what she calls the Simple Noun Phrase Hypothesis (SH), according to which the two phrases have a different structure. The SH but not the HPH can account for a large number of facts that are reviewed in section 3. The strongest argument in favor of the SH is the different result of PP extraposition in (22):

(22)
a. Two reviews have been reprinted of Helen's first symphony.
b. *Two of those reviews have been reprinted of Helen's first symphony.
c. Those reviews have been reprinted of Helen's first symphony.

The reason for the ungrammaticality of (22b) should not be directly attributed to the definiteness of the noun phrase since (22c) is perfectly acceptable, but to a violation of the cycle. The cycle appears not to be violated in (22a). This, according to Selkirk, suggests that the noun phrase in (23b), parallel to (22b), is structurally more complex than the one in (23a), parallel to (22a).

(23)
a. Two reviews of Helen's first symphony have been reprinted.
b. Two of those reviews of Helen's first symphony have been reprinted.

A similar argument is given for French by Milner (1978b: 71). While extraction out of the partitive PP is ungrammatical in (24), extraction out of the constituent that follows the quantifier in (25) is possible. This implies that the XP in (25) cannot be the PP that we find in (24). Notice that this also holds of (25b) in spite of the presence of the preposition de (see section 3.3.3).

(24)
*C’est de Zola que j’ai lu [deux [PP des livres [PP t]]].
it is of Zola that I have read two of-the books

(25)
a. C’est de Zola que j’ai lu [deux [XP livres [PP t]]].
it is of Zola that I have read two books
b. C’est de Zola que j’ai lu [beaucoup [XP de livres [PP t]]].
it is of Zola that I have read many of books

The conclusion that the quantitative phrase (namely the noun (phrase) immediately following the quantifier) is different from the partitive phrase is confirmed by the fact that they cannot be coordinated, as shown in (26).

(26)
a. J’ai reçu beaucoup de voisins et d’ amis.
I have received many of neighbors and of friends
b. J’ai reçu beaucoup de mes voisins et de mes amis.
I have received many of my neighbors and of my friends
c. *J’ai reçu beaucoup de mes voisins et d’ amis

Milner (1978b: 81ff.) suggests that the quantitative phrase is an N′, while the partitive phrase is a N″. This is also shown by the fact that personal pronouns, which are certainly full nominal phrases (of category N″ in terms of the theory of the time), can appear only as partitive phrases and not as quantitative phrases:

(27)
un de nous/vous/eux
one of us/you/them
A further argument against the HPH is discussed in Belletti (1979: 1546). The two sentences in (28) have different semantic properties:

(28)
a. Ho letto cinque libri che mi avevi prestato.
b. Ho letto cinque dei libri che mi avevi prestato.
have.1Sg read five (of the) books that to-me had.2Sg lent

In (28a), the books that have been read are five and coincide with the books that have been lent. In (28b) the books that have been read are a subset of the books that have been lent, which are presupposed to be more than five.

subsection.heading: 2.1.3 The first element of the partitive construction
subsection.p: In EST terms it is straightforward to consider the quantifier as an article in the quantified construction. If the two constructions in (1) and (6) do not have a common deep structure, the status of the first part of the partitive construction remains open.
Jackendoff (1977: 110ff.) adopts the SH and introduces a PRO in the partitive construction, as shown in (29).

Milner (1978b: 83ff.) provides the following arguments to analyze the first part of the partitive construction (the quantifier many in many of the men or the constituent many men in many men of those . . . ) as a full noun phrase (N″). In French it has the form of a pronoun, not of a determiner, in the pairs quelque/ quelques-uns (‘some’) and chaque/chacun (‘each’). The same is true in Italian, as shown in (30b):

(30)
a. ogni/qualche ragazzo vs. *ognun/*qualcun ragazzo
each/some boy
b. *ogni/*qualche di loro vs. ognuno/qualcuno di loro
each/some of them
In certain contexts, the N″ is explicit, as in (31):

(31)
[N″ Quatre peintures] de celles qui avaient été volées ont été retrouvées.
four pictures of those that-Agr had been stolen have been recovered
The first element can be the pronoun celui, or the interrogative lequel, as in (32):

(32)
a. Celui des livres de Zola que j’ai lu.
the one of-the books of Zola that I have read
b. Lequel de ces livres avez-vous lu?
which of these books have you read?
The quantitative clitic en can co-occur with a partitive phrase, as in (33):

(33)
a. J’en ai pris un kilo de celles-ci.
b. J’en ai pris dix de celles-ci.
c. J’en ai pris beaucoup de celles-ci.
I EN have taken a kilo/ten/many of these

Structure (34), proposed by Milner (1978b: 124, ex. 3.11), captures the different nature of the quantitative and the partitive complements of a quantity expression, the fact that both are in a selectional relation to it, and the fact that they can co-occur (on this also see section 3). A right-adjunction movement adjoins the Partitive Phrase to N′ to derive the correct word order. In (34), the Partitive Phrase is realized by a collective noun phrase, but the analysis is explicitly extended to the classical quantitative and partitive noun phrases discussed in (31–33).

The crucial difference between (29) and (34) is that in the former the partitive is base-generated under N′ as a complement of N, while in the latter this position is derived by rightward movement which adjoins the complement of the quantifier under N′. In our proposal, presented in section 3, we keep the relationship between Q and the partitive PP while doing away with rightward adjunction.

subsection.heading: 2.2 GB proposals
subsection.p: Government-and-Binding approaches are driven by the search for general principles of UG that constrain movement of constituents and the occurrence of anaphoric elements. Phrase-structure issues are no longer crucial in this period and remain in the background. In this perspective, the syntax of quantitative and partitive constructions in French, Italian, and Dutch becomes a focus of general interest due to the fact that these languages display a quantitative clitic pronoun that clearly is a subpart of the phrase. As a consequence, these languages show how the extraction of the partitive clitic is constrained by the general principles of Government and Binding giving rise to crucial asymmetries (cf. Belletti and Rizzi 1981; Burzio 1986). The core cases are given in (35–37), from Belletti and Rizzi (1981):

(35)
a. Tre settimane
passano rapidamente.
three weeks
elapse rapidly
b. *Tre ne passano rapidamente.
three NE elapse rapidly
c. Tre [e]
passano rapidamente.
three
elapse rapidly

(36)
a. Gianni
trascorrerà tre settimane a Milano.
Gianni
will spend three weeks in Milan
b. Gianni ne trascorrerà tre a Milano.
Gianni NE will spend three in Milan
c. *Gianni
trascorrerà tre [e] a Milano.
Gianni
will spend three in Milan

(37)
a. Gianni
è rimasto tre settimane a Milano.
Gianni
remained three weeks in Milan
b. *Gianni ne è rimasto tre a Milano.
Gianni NE remained three in Milan
c. *Gianni
è rimasto tre [e] a Milano.
Gianni
remained three in Milan

The examples in (35) shows that extraction of ne is impossible from a preverbal subject; an empty category is found instead. In (36) ne is obligatory if it binds an empty category in object position. The selected direct object in (36) contrasts with the adverbial phrase in (37).

The [e] ∼ne alternation given in (35–37) is captured by Belletti and Rizzi (1981) by means of general requirements of proper binding (cf. the Proper Binding Condition proposed by Fiengo 1974). In the case of subjects, ne does not c-command its trace, hence the ungrammaticality of (35b). In the case of objects, ne c-commands its trace, hence the grammaticality of (36b). In the case of adjuncts, ne extraction causes a subjacency violation, hence the ungrammaticality of (37b). As for the distribution of the null category inside the quantified noun phrase, Belletti and Rizzi take it to be PRO (as originally proposed in Kayne 1979: Appendix): PRO is allowed in subject position (35c), but forbidden in object and in adjunct position, where it is governed by the verb, (36c) and (37c). 2
This analysis is supported by data from Czech, where the genitive clitic jich can be extracted from both subjects and objects (Toman 1986: 131).

(38)
a. Tehdy jich nêpolik podepsalo ten dopis. Czech
then of-them some have signed that letter
b. Tehdy jich Petr nalezl pêt.
then of-them Petr found five

Czech is a language with second-position clitic pronouns. According to current analyses, the clitic position is higher than the subject position. This means that a clitic pronoun c-commands its trace even when it is extracted out of a subject.

The internal structure assumed by Belletti and Rizzi (1981) for quantified phrases is (39). However, nothing of their proposal hinges on it. The categorial status of PRO in (39) is not explicitly stated. It is clear from the discussion that it is an N′ (see section 4.1 for further discussion). According to Rizzi (1979), the phonosyntactic processes that rule the occurrence of the competing forms un/uno in (40) can be derived from the presence of an empty category immediately following uno:

(40)
a. un(*o) lunghissimo libro
b. un(*o) libro lunghissimo
a book very-long
c. un*(o)
lunghissimo
‘a very long one’

Rizzi proposes a different level of attachment for prenominal and postnominal adjectives: The former are attached to N′, and trigger truncation (41a), while the latter are attached to N″ and cannot trigger truncation (41b). The same structure applies for the possessive phrase di Mario (‘of Mario’) in (41b):

Rizzi does not address the issue of the position of a partitive phrase in this construction. However, we may suppose that, since it triggers the same effect as a possessive phrase (cf. uno/*un di quei ragazzi ‘one of those boys’), it is attached to N″ and not to N′, contrary to Jackendoff's (1977) structure (29) and Milner's (1978b) structure (34). We will turn to the categorial status of the empty category bound by ne in section 4.

subsection.heading: 2.3 The functional structure of quantified noun phrases
subsection.p: At the end of the 1980s, the study of the internal structure of noun phrases became a focus of research based on a wider set of languages, including Hungarian (Szabolcsi 1987), Hebrew (Ritter 1988), and Romanian (Grosu 1988). The major topic of this research is the investigation of functional heads inside the noun phrase, which is parallel in many crucial respects to the structure of the sentence. A related trend of research follows Cinque (1994, already circulating in 1990), in taking adnominal adjectives to fill functional specifiers in the noun phrase structure. Both issues are central to the internal structure of quantitative and partitive phrases, since in the approaches reviewed earlier, the distinction between determiners and adjectives was not clear, and quantifiers were considered as part of this large class of prenominal modifiers.

Due to the theoretical and chronological gap between EST and post-GB proposals, most of this literature is negligent of the results arrived at in the 1960s and 1970s on the structure of quantitative and partitive phrases, and many questions are reconsidered without building on the knowledge arrived at in the EST studies.

subsection.heading: 2.3.1 The DP Hypothesis
subsection.p: Abney (1987: 271) places quantifiers in D, i.e., in a head position. In order to derive their co-occurrence with possessors in Hungarian (42) (see also Szabolcsi 1987) and their (almost) complementary distribution with possessors in English (43), Abney proposes the constraint in (44), which applies to English, but not to Hungarian:

(42)
a. Peter minden kalapja
b. Peter ezen/azon kalapja
c. Peter valamennyi kalapja
d. Peter mindket kalapja
e. Peter semelyik kalapja

(43)
a. John's every wish
b. *John's this/that wish
c. *John's each wish
d. *John's both wishes
e. *John's neither wish
(44) Agr in D does not co-occur with lexical determiners.

One further piece of evidence in favor of the common position of D and Q in one and the same head is the possibility of N-to-D movement which adjoins a noun such as one to a Q such as every or some in (45a) (Abney's 1987: 286, ex. 309b), and the relative position of the AP in (45b) (Abney's 1987: 287, ex. 312), which would otherwise be mysterious in English (cf. some good guy, where the adjective precedes the noun). Structure (45) is intended to account for everything and something as well, and to parallel data in other languages.

However, the analysis in (45) cannot account for parallel Italian data. According to Cinque (1994), in Italian a common noun such as cosa in (46a) often moves across an adjective to an intermediate functional head. This movement leaves the adjective unaffected. Incorporation of the noun cosa into the quantifier qualche as in (46b), however, not only changes the gender features on the whole construction, but also triggers what appears to be an overt marking of partitive Case on the adjective, namely the preposition di (also see section 3.4).

(46)
a. una cosa buona
a thing good.Fem
‘a good thing’
b. qualcosa di buono
something of good.Masc
‘something good’
Furthermore, only predicative adjectives can appear in this construction, as shown by the ungrammaticality of (47a). This is not expected in an analysis like (45):

(47)
a. *qualcosa di mero/principale / *Questa cosa è mera/principale.
something of mere/main
this thing is mere/main
b. qualcosa di buono / Questa cosa è buona.
something of good
this thing is good

The Italian examples and their English glosses suggest that pronominal quantifiers occurring with predicative adjectives, like someone and something in English, cannot be analyzed as the simple result of N-to-D movement. We delay a more principled analysis to section 3.4, in which we take into account the apparent different behavior of qualcuno (‘somebody’) pointed out to us by R. Zamparelli (p.c.).

Later in the same chapter, Abney (1987: 339ff.) takes different kinds of quantifier into account and proposes that they are adjectives of a special kind and therefore occupy a (head) position lower than D and a position higher than descriptive adjectives in structure (48) (Abney's 1987: 287, ex. 312). The position of many in (48) is also assumed for cardinals and other quantifiers and supported by a parallelism between comparative adjectives and quantifiers which also co-occur with a partitive PP. Abney (1987: 344) takes this PP to be the complement of an empty N that can only be the complement of Q in structures like (49) or of comparative A in structures like (50) (Abney's 1987: 344, ex. 413).

The parallelism between comparative and superlative structures on the one hand and partitive structures on the other is not new in the literature (also cf. Bresnan 1973b and Milner 1978: 121). However, Milner (1978b) already noticed that the partitive phrase is the complement of the degree word and not of the adjective. Furthermore, it does not form a constituent with the NP:

(51)
a. *Books of those you lent me, I've read only the best.
b. *Books of those you lent me, I've read only some.

A second problem that can be found with (50) is quite reminiscent of Jackendoff's (1977) structure in (29). The assumption is that the partitive PP can be selected only by an empty N. This assumption is at the same time quite implausible (empty elements should not, in principle, have selectional features) and incorrect, as shown in (52). The partitive phrase can co-occur with lexical nouns as in (52a, b), and cannot occur when the quantifier is preceded by a determiner (irrespectively of the (c)overt status of the preceding N), as in (52c, d):

(52)
a. the best books of those you lent me
b. many books of those you lent me
c. *the many books of those you lent me
d. *the many of the books you lent me

Undoubtedly, the analysis in (48) would have the advantage of unifying noun phrases such as many children parallel to (1a) with noun phrases such as the many children parallel to (2a, a′). But the apparent advantage is marred by the fact that it raises more problems than it solves. We see in section 2.3.3 that there is cross-linguistic evidence to propose that many children and the many children are structures of different sorts.

subsection.heading: 2.3.2 The QP Hypothesis
subsection.p: Although not interested in the internal structure of quantified noun phrases, Sportiche (1988) is the first work in the generative literature to propose that a quantifier is external to the noun phrase. Sportiche claims that the universal quantifier is adjoined to NP. This proposal, interacting with the hypothesis that the subject is generated VP-internally (Koopman and Sportiche 1985, later published as 1991b), allows him to provide a derivational analysis of floating quantifiers, as shown in (53):

(53)
a. [IP [NP Les enfants] ont [VP [NP tous [NP t]] vu ce film]].
b. [IP [NP The children] have [VP [NP all [NP t]] seen this film]].

In (53) the discontinuous word order of the quantified noun phrase is derived by movement of the NP subject from the VP internal position to [Spec, IP], leaving the quantifier in its D-structure position.

In the spirit of the DP hypothesis, Giusti (1990) and Cardinaletti and Giusti (1992) propose that the quantifier is a head, higher than DP. This allows them to analyze quantitative ne in Italian as binding a full DP (see section 4.3.2), parallel to other instances of clitics, such as accusative lo (‘him’), la (‘her’), li (‘them-masc’), le (‘them-fem’), which co-occur with universal quantifiers:

(54)
a. Nei ho visti [QP
molti [DP ti]].
NE have.1Sg seen many
b. Lii ho visti [QP
tutti [DP ti]].
them have.1Sg seen
all

Example (54) also reinforces Sportiche's (1988) idea that floating is the side-effect of independent movement, interacting with the QP structure. It also shows that with respect to clitic extraction, universal and existential quantifiers behave alike.

For existential quantifiers, Cardinaletti and Giusti (1992) propose the structure in (55), where the Q is conceived of as a diadic element with two internal arguments: the indefinite DP (which we call quantitative DP) and the partitive PP.

This analysis is motivated by the fact that the selectional properties of Q determine both the features on the (quantitative) DP and the occurrence of the partitive PP. For example, universal quantifiers such as tutti (‘all’) and entrambi (‘both’) select a definite DP as in tutti i ragazzi (‘all the boys’), and do not select a partitive PP as in *tutti dei ragazzi (all of the boys). 3 Existential quantifiers such as molti (‘many’) and alcuni (‘some’) and distributive quantifiers such as ogni (‘every’) and ciascun(o) (‘each’) can select both a quantitative DP and a partitive PP, as in molti ragazzi di quelli che conosco (‘many boys of those I know’) and ogni ragazzo di quelli che conosco (‘every boy of those I know’). This is analyzed in detail in section 3.

In this trend of research, Shlonsky (1991) for Hebrew and Giusti (1991a) for Italian independently propose that quantifiers are heads, higher than DP, and that the DP embedded under Q′ can move out of the QP. Although the argument is based on universal quantifiers, which do not usually appear with quantitative and partitive phrases, we present it in some detail since it is extended to quantifiers that co-occur with quantitative and partitive phrases later in this chapter. Shlonsky (1991) motivates his proposal on the basis of a marking of agreement that appears on the head Q in Hebrew when the DP is moved, leaving Q in situ, cf. (56):

(56)
a. [QP
kol [DP
ha-yeladim]] yašnu.
all
the children slept
b.
[DP
ha-yeladim]i
yašnu [QP t’i [Q′
kulam [DP ti]].
the children slept
all
Notice that [Spec, QP] not only serves as an escape hatch, but can also be the final landing site for DP, obtaining a post nominal position for Q: see (57).

(57)
a. [QP kol [DP ha-yeladim]]
ohavim le-saxek.
all the children love to-play
b. [QP [DP ha-yeladim]i [Q′ kulam [DP ti]]]
ohavim le-saxek.
the children all love to-play

Following a suggestion by Sportiche (p.c.), Giusti (1991a) extends Shlonsky's analysis of DP-to-[Spec, QP] movement in Hebrew to personal pronouns in various languages, such as French (58), English (59), and optionally Italian (60).

(58)
a. *[QP tous [DP eux]]
b. [QP [DP eux] [Q′ tous [DP t]]

(59)
a. *[QP all [DP them]]
b. [QP [DP them] [Q′ all [DP t]]

(60)
a. [QP tutti [DP loro]]
b. [QP [DP loro] [Q′ tutti [DP t]]

Giusti (1994) further shows that the same phenomenon is present in different languages and with other kinds of quantifiers. For example, in Hebrew it is also found with existential quantifiers, as in (61):

(61)
a. [QP
meat [DP yeladim]]/ [QP
meat [DP yeladot]]
ohavim le-saxek.
few boys/
few girls
love to-play
b. [QP [DP
yeladim] [Q′ meatim [DP t]]/ [QP [DP
yeladot [Q′ meatot [DP t]]
ohavim le-saxek.
boys few-Masc.Pl/
girls few-Fem.Pl love to-play
In Romanian, DP-movement to [Spec, QP] is found with both universal and existential quantifiers, provided that the DP is not heavily modified, as shown in (62):

(62)
a. am vǎzut pe [QP [DP copii-i] [Q′ to tcedil i [DP t]]].
[I] have seen Acc children-the all
b. am vǎzut
[QP [DP copii] [Q′ mul tcedil i [DP t]]].
[I] have seen
children many

The hypothesis that Q is a head, embedding a DP (in contrast with determiners and adjectives, which are internal to DP) and projecting a Specifier position, can account in a principled way for the data in (56–62), which would otherwise appear quite idiosyncratic.

A final piece of evidence in favor of the structure in (55) is that in some marginal cases like (63) many occurs on the left of a determiner, parallel to all in (64), and differently from many in (2a′).

(63)
a. many a good student 4
b. many another man

(64)
a. all the good students
b. all the other men

The structure in (55) can also give a unified analysis to simple quantified noun phrases such as many children and structures like (63–64), with the additional, quite costless assumption of a null indefinite determiner in the D position in the complement of an existential Q, as in (65a). Structure (65b) shows absence of number agreement between the quantifier and the DP, which displays a singular indefinite article. 5 In (65c), the complement of a universal quantifier displays a definite determiner:

(65)
a. [QP [Q many] [DP [D Ø] [ . . . [NP men]]]]
b. [QP [Q many] [DP [D a] [ . . . [NP man]]]]
c. [QP [Q all] [DP [D the] [ . . . [NP men]]]]
Universal quantifiers can also co-occur with a null determiner in English (66a), but not in many other languages, e.g., Italian (66b):

(66)
a. [QP [Q all] [DP [D Ø] [ . . . [NP men]]]] are mortal
b. [QP [Q tutti] [DP [D gli] [ . . . [NP uomini]]]] sono mortali

The null determiner in English (66a) is the null determiner found in generic noun phrases independently of the presence of the quantifier (cf. Matthewson 2001). This null determiner is not found in Italian (see Longobardi 1994 and Chierchia 1998 for analyses of this fact).

To summarize the results of this section, the QP-hypothesis claims that Q is a head external to the DP and that Q projects a full QP level. This hypothesis accounts for the facts in (67) which builds a diagnostics for the Q status:

(67)
A diagnostics for quantifiers:
Q can precede definite as well as indefinite articles.
Q can co-occur with pronouns.
Q allows leftward movement of the DP to an immediately adjacent position which builds a constituent with Q and can straightfowardly be analyzed as [Spec, QP].
Different classes of Q correlate with the (in)definiteness of the embedded DP. This phenomenon will be accounted for in terms of selectional properties of Qs in section 3.
Q can occur in discontinuous position in a number of languages, contrary to other nominal modifiers and determiners.

subsection.heading: 2.3.3 The AP Hypothesis
subsection.p: The QP hypothesis does not deal with the case of quantifiers that can be preceded by a determiner as in (2a′) the many boys. It requires an additional hypothesis that analyzes some quantity expressions as merged in adjectival position inside the DP, as in (68) (cf. Giusti 1991a, 1993). We will call this the AP-hypothesis. The AP-hypothesis, combined with the QP-hypothesis in (55), predicts that not all quantifiers can be quantity adjectives and vice versa. For example all, some, and both are not adjectives and cannot occur after a determiner. This explains the ungrammaticality of (3a), (4a), and (5a).

It is often assumed in the literature that the quantifiers that can occur after a determiner are weak quantifiers (in the sense of Milsark 1977). But this is not completely true. S'm, the weak counterpart of some, cannot appear after a determiner in (69a), or as a predicative adjective in (69b): 6

(69)
a. The many/three/several/*some/*s'm students that I know are all lazy.
b. ?The students that I know are many/three/several/*some/*s'm.

If we consider the distribution of quantity adjectives from a cross-linguistic perspective, it appears accidental that quantity adjectives in English are a subset of weak quantifiers. In German (70b) and Dutch (70c), for example, the counterparts of the English strong quantifier most in (70a) are only adjectival in nature:

(70)
a. Most children are nice.
b. Die meisten Kinder sind nett. German
c. De meeste kinderen zijn aardig. Dutch

Meisten in (70b) and meeste in (70c) clearly display the adjectival inflectional morphology and must be preceded by a (definite) determiner. This is also found with German universal quantity adjective ganzen (‘all’) in (71a) and can be the case of beiden (‘both’) in (71b) and vielen (‘many’) in (71c):

(71)
a. Die ganzen Kinder sind da.
the all children are here
b. Die beiden Kinder sind da.
the both children are here
c. Diese vielen Kinder sind da.
these many children are here

Ganz(en) is not a Q, it can have adjectival or adverbial status (meaning ‘entirely’, ‘completely’). Beide(n) and viele(n) are ambiguous between Q and A status and can be found in different constructions. When beide and viele are Qs, they have the inflectional morphology of a determiner. 7 This idiosyncrasy in the possibility for a lexical item expressing quantity to be a quantifier, a quantity adjective, or both, is expected under the hypothesis that these elements can have different categorial status, independent of the meaning of a given element. In each language a given element is assigned either status or both. What is striking is that the syntactic behavior directly depends on the categorial status of the element, not on its semantic value.

The combination of the QP and the AP hypotheses also predicts the co-occurrence of two quantifiers in one and the same noun phrase, as in (72). It is, however, sufficiently restricted as to predict the ungrammaticality of some logically possible combinations as in (73). 8

(72)
a. tutti questi duecentoquaranta compiti da correggere
b. all these two hundred and forty tests to check
c. tutti questi molti(ssimi)/pochi(ssimi) compiti da correggere
d. all these (very) many/few tests to check
e. entrambi questi due ragazzi
f. both these two boys
g. some
twenty tests to check
h. no
two tests

(73)
a. *twenty some
children
b. *two no
tests
c. tutti questi (*alcuni) compiti da correggere
d. all these (*some) tests to check

Notice that the reason for the ungrammaticality of (73) is not necessarily the semantic incompatibility of the two quantifiers. It is rather the fact that in English, some and no are not quantity adjectives and cannot appear inside a DP in adjectival position. The same is true for Italian alcuni. Notice also that the appearance of a quantity adjective inside the partitive PP in (74) does not give rise to a violation of the partitive constraint, contrary to what is found with quantifiers in (75) (cf. (14) above, n. 21, and Casadio 1995: n. 3):

(74)
a. molti di questi duecentoquaranta compiti da correggere
b. many of these two hundred and forty tests to check
c. tre delle poche mele che ho
d. three of the few apples that I have

(75)
a. *molti di duecentoquaranta compiti da correggere
b. *many of two hundred and forty tests to check
c. *tre di poche mele (che ho)
d. *three of few apples (that I have)
At the end of the previous sections we listed a number of phenomena arising with quantifiers. We will now observe that they do not arise with quantity adjectives.

When quantifiers are in object position in Italian, they allow for the extraction of a clitic pronoun from the DP, as shown in (54). This possibility does not arise with other modifiers of the noun, since modifiers are internal to the DP and cannot be left in place by DP extraction. Quantity adjectives give the same result as other adjective in (76a–b).

(76)
a. *Ne/*Li ho comprati (gli) interessanti [t].
NE/them have.1Sg bought (the) interesting [t]
b. *Ne/*Li ho comprati i tre [t].
NE/them have.1Sg bought the three [t]
c. Ne ho letto i tre racconti [PP t].
CL have.1Sg read-Masc.Sg the three short stories

Notice that ne-extraction is allowed over a definite article in (76c) where ne binds a constituent (a genitive PP). A further argument on this line is provided by the discussion on the Serbo-Croatian data in (84–85).
Quantifiers can embed an empty DP in subject position and in the complement of a PP, as in (77) (for the interpretation of the empty noun phrase, see section 3.3.4):

(77)
a. Tre/ alcuni/ tutti/ entrambi sono arrivati ieri.
b. Three/ some/ all/ both are arrived yesterday.
c. Ieri ho parlato con tre/alcuni/tutti/entrambi.
d. Yesterday I spoke to three/some/all/ both.
This is not found with other modifiers of the noun phrase:

(78)
a. *Simpatici sono arrivati ieri.
b. *Nice arrived yesterday.
c. *Ieri ho parlato con simpatici.
d. *Yesterday I spoke to nice.

The contrasts in (72–76) and (77–78) show that all types of quantifier show comparable behavior in occurring with a clitic pronoun and/or an empty noun phrase. Their behavior is crucially different from adjectives, as shown by (76) and (78).

Existential quantity adjectives (numerals and vague numerals) do not select a partitive PP (see section 3.1), as shown by the contrast in (79a, b), contrary to existential quantifiers, as in (79c). This is not predicted if the cardinal is one and the same element in all the cases in (79).

(79)
a. *questi tre dei partecipanti
these three of-the participants
b. questi tre
partecipanti
c. tre
dei partecipanti

Romanian provides us with an interesting minimal pair. Dual universal quantity can be expressed either by a quantifier: amîndoi, or by a quantity adjective: ambii. 9 The syntactic hehavior of these two elements is particularly significative. Amîndoi is parallel to to tcedil i (‘all’) in embedding a full definite DP, while ambii is in all respects a prenominal adjective. 10 In (80) we observe that the enclitic article is on the noun (80a) or on the prenominal adjective (80b), but never on the quantifier (80c). This shows that the quantifiers amîndoi and to tcedil i are not part of the functional projection of the noun phrase: they immediately embed a DP.

(80)
a. Au venit amîndoi / to tcedil i bǎie tcedil ii frumoşi. Romanian
have arrived both / all boys-the nice
b. Au venit amîndoi / to tcedil i frumoşii bǎie tcedil i.
have arrived both / all nice-the boys
c. *Au venit amîndoii / to tcedil ii bǎie tcedil i (frumoşi).
have arrived both-the / all-the boys nice

Quite the opposite holds of the quantifier ambii, which is always inflected for the enclitic article (81b, c). Other prenominal adjectives such as biet (‘poor’) must also bear the definite article in definite descriptions. Parallel to biet, ambii precedes other prenominal modifiers, as in (81b).

(81)
a. *Au venit ambi/bie tcedil i bǎie tcedil ii (frumoşi). Romanian
have arrived both/poor boys-the nice
b. Au venit ambii/bie tcedil ii (frumoşi) bǎie tcedil;i
c. Au venit ambii/bie tcedil;ii bǎie tcedil;i (frumoşi)
have arrived both-the/poor-the boys nice

If floating and clitic-extraction are the result of DP movement, as claimed by Sportiche (1988) and Giusti (1990), among others, it is predicted that only amîndoi/to tcedil;i, but not ambii, occur in floating constructions. The same holds for clitic extraction, given that the clitic starts in a DP position. The two predictions are borne out, as can be seen in (82):

(82)
a. Bǎie tcedil;ii frumoşi au venit amîndoi /to tcedil;i /*ambi(i). Romanian
children-the nice have arrived both /all /both
b. I-am
vǎzut pe amîndoi /to tcedil;i /*ambi(i).
[I] them have
seen Acc both /all /both

As seen in (62) above, Romanian allows a postnominal position of the quantifier, parallel to Hebrew (57) and (61). If this is due to movement of the DP to [Spec, QP], we expect that only amîndoi/to tcedil;i, but not ambii can occur in postnominal position, as shown in (83). Example (83b) shows that ambii behaves like the prenominal adjective bie tcedil;i in that it is not able to co-occur with a pronoun:

(83)
a. noi amîndoi / to tcedil;i
we both / all
b. *noi ambi(i) / bie tcedil;i(i)
we both-(the) / poor-(the)

Slavic languages provide a different set of phenomena that distinguish quantifiers and quantity adjectives, as discussed in Giusti and Leko (1996, 2001) for Serbian–Croatian. Since pronouns can be inflected for genitive in these languages, they can occur as the complement of existential quantifiers. This is not the case with quantity adjectives, which agree with the noun and do not assign Case to it (see section 3.3.1).

In (84a) mnogo (‘many’) appears with a genititve DP, studenata, or a strong pronoun, njih. In (84b) the pronoun is clitic and must be extracted out of the QP. The presence of the pronoun is obligatory in (84):

(84)
a. Vidio sam mnogo studenata / njih. Serbian–Croatian
saw.1Sg Cl.Aux many students.Gen.Pl / them.Gen.Pl
b. Vidio sam ih mnogo.
saw.1Sg Cl.Aux them.Cl.Gen.Pl many
‘I saw a lot of them.’

Neither possibility is available with a quantity adjective which agrees with the following noun for accusative Case (assigned by the verb) and other phi-features in (85a). In (85b) it is shown that a quantity adjective cannot occur with a pronoun, irrespective of its strong or clitic nature. It can only occur in an elliptical construction:

(85)
a. Vidio sam mnoge studente / *njih. Serbian–Croatian
[I] saw Cl.Aux many.Acc.Pl students.Acc.Pl / them.Gen.Pl
b. Vidio sam (*ih) mnoge (*njih).
[I] saw Cl.Aux them.Cl.Acc.Pl many.Acc.Pl
A comparable argument can be build for German. In (86) we make a parallelism between quantifiers such as alle and beide, which can occur with a pronoun, and the adjective ganze, which cannot:

(86)
a. wir alle (we all) German
b. wir beide (we both)
c. *wir ganze(n) (we both)

Notice that the obligatory presence of a definite determiner preceding a quantity adjective is found only in languages that display the definite article. In a Slavic language such as Bosnian–Croatian–Serbian, which does not display a definite article, quantity adjectives may appear with no definite article. They therefore provide a good case to dispense with a possible criticism to our test of clitic extraction in (72–76), showing that it is not the presence of the determiner that blocks clitic extraction but the fact that the clitic binds the whole DP, which excludes a quantifier but includes a quantity adjective.

To summarize, we have proposed that only some quantifiers can occur in adjectival position. We call them quantity adjectives. The possibility to be merged in such a position is due to their categorial status which must be listed in the lexicon. This claim is supported by their syntactic hehavior. In (87) we find a set of phenomena which can build a diagnostics for quantity adjectives, which can be now contrasted with the diagnostics for quantifiers given in (67).

(87)
A diagnostics for quantity adjectives:
Quantity adjectives are preceded by a determiner (in languages that have a definite article).
Quantity adjectives cannot occur with a pronoun.
Quantity adjectives do not allow extraction of the part of the DP that does not contain it.
Quantity adjectives cannot appear in discontinuous position (in languages in which adjectives cannot do so).
Quantity adjectives do not select a partitive PP.

subsection.heading: 2.3.4 A recent attempt at unification
subsection.p: Given the discussion so far, the unification of many in many boys (see (1a)) and the many boys (see (2a′)) cannot be considered as the null hypothesis and needs argumentation. Such an argumentation is given by Zamparelli (1995), who endorses a general proposal about the structure of noun phrases designed to capture, by means of the X-bar theoretic schema in (88), the different interpretive properties of several types of determiners as classified in the semantic tradition of Milsark (1977) and Barwise and Cooper (1981). The structure in (88) provides different positions for different kinds of determiner. SD (strong determiner) is the position where strong quantifiers, such as both, most, every, and each, and determiners, such as demonstratives and the definite article, are inserted. PD (predicative determiner) is the position where the indefinite article a and weak quantifiers such as cardinals and vague numerals are inserted. KI (Kind) is the projection that denotes the kind in the semantic interpretation.

Although in (88) both strong and weak quantifiers are inserted in head positions, Zamparelli's proposal is to be considered in the line of research that treats quantifiers as a special type of adjective. He follows the semantic tradition of Milsark's (1977), according to which strong quantifiers are determiners while weak quantifiers are modifiers, and the syntactic hypothesis of Abney (1987) and Bernstein (1993b) that (at least some) prenominal adjectives are merged into functional heads of the extended projection of the noun.

The immediate appeal of (88) is that it derives the well-known semantic properties of quantifiers in the syntax. The ambiguity between the strong and weak reading of existential quantifiers (cardinals and vague numerals) is accounted for by assuming that some quantifiers can be inserted either in PD (in which case they are weak) or in SD (in which case they are strong). Other quantifiers can only be inserted in SD and cannot be lowered to PD. 11

Another advantage of (88) is that it establishes a correlation between each layer and a different type of clitic element in Italian: SDP is the clitic displaying Agr features such as the accusative lo, la, li, le; PDP is the uninflected clitic lo which resumes a predicate; while KIP corresponds to the quantitative clitic ne (thereby predicting that ne can be extracted only from weak quantifiers; see also section 3.3.1).

Zamparelli assumes that the complete structure in (88) is always projected when the noun phrase is in argument position. We restrict our review of Zamparelli's hypothesis to such a case. In (89) we observe a noun phrase in object position. In (89a) we see the structure of a weak noun phrase, in (89b) that of a bare plural, and in (89c) the structure of a strong noun phrase.

(89)
a. I am looking for [SDP SD [PDP two [NP . . . nice people]]].
b. I am looking for [SDP SD [PDP PD[plural/mass]
[NP . . . nice people]]].
c. I am looking for [SDP every [PDP PD[sing]
[NP . . . nice man]]].

In (89a) the weak interpretation is obtained by not moving the quantifier to SD. SD is empty and is licensed by the verb. In (89b) the same holds for SD, but PD is also empty and needs to be licensed. This is obtained, stipulatively, by assuming that the empty SD requires a [plural/mass] feature in PD, and it is licensed by virtue of this requirement. In (89c) we see the case of a strong quantifier that occupies the SD position and licenses the empty PD, to which it assigns a [sing] feature.

This proposal predicts the co-occurrence of an element in SD and an element in PD. An example of such a case is the by now notorious case of (2a′), which is attributed the structure in (90a). However, Zamparelli's proposal cannot account for the unacceptability of (90b), which should have the same structure:

(90)
a. [SDP [SD these] [PDP many [NP . . . men]]]
b. *[SDP [SD every] [PDP a [NP man]]]
In order to overcome this problem, Zamparelli (1995: 118) proposes the principle of redundancy in (91).
(91) Two functional words Fi, Fj within the same DP give an impossible representation if the meaning of Fi entails the meaning of Fj or vice-versa.

Principle (91) rules out the insertion of two quantifiers with the same function. In (90b) every would be redundant with the weak quantifier a. However, (91) is contradicted by the Ladin construction ‘one a N′ discussed in Benincà and Haiman (1992) and reported in (92), where the two elements apparently have the same interpretation and nevertheless do not exclude each other:

(92)
a. Da øna na skwadra (eso eng pasa a tr&egr;j). Badiot
from one a team ([we] passed to three)
‘From a team we grew to three.’
b. (L’&egr;rt kunts&egr;tuala), una na rama dl &egr;rt visiva. Gardena
(the art conceptual), one a branch of-the art visual
‘conceptual art, one branch of visual art.’

Notice that the data in (92) are in many respects parallel to the case of English many a good student presented in (63). And they can be straightforwardly captured by the analysis in (55) and (65) given above. Furthermore, (89a) claims that weak quantifiers in PD co-occur with an empty determiner in SD. This appears to be consistent with what we know about English, but cannot be maintained for Italian. In English (93), both the quantifier many and the descriptive adjective good can introduce the DP. In Italian (94), the quantifier molti but not the adjective bravi can introduce a DP in subject position:

(93)
a. Many students have passed the exam.
b. Good students have passed the exam.

(94)
a. Molti studenti hanno superato l’esame.
b. *Bravi studenti hanno superato l’esame.

The contrast between (93) and (94) shows that at least in Italian it is impossible to claim that molti is an adjective preceded by a null determiner, given that null determiners are banned in the IP-subject position. The analysis proposed in sections 2.3.2–2.3.3 does not have this problem and can unify the analysis for Italian and English by considering many in (93a) and molti in (94a) as quantifiers which embed a quantitative (indefinite) DP.

Finally, in contrast with our proposals in (55) and (68) above, Zamparelli's structure (88) cannot derive the case in which a quantifier precedes a strong (definite) determiner that is in turn followed by a weak quantifier, as in (95) and parallel structures cross-linguistically.

(95)
a. all these very many children
b. both these two children

To accommodate for this, Zamparelli proposes that tutti, and supposedly also both and half, are external to the noun phrase structure and adjoined as a constituent to SDP, parallel to what is proposed by Sportiche (1988). But this fails to capture the parallelisms among quantifiers noticed earlier in (65), while other determiners behave differently, as in the unacceptable (76a, b).

subsection.heading: 3 A refinement of the QP Hypothesis
subsection.p: In section 2.3.2 we observed that the QP hypothesis represented in (55) is flexible enough to account for a range of different selectional properties found with different classes of quantifiers. We now focus on the different properties of different classes of quantifiers and refine the structure proposed in (55), making it compatible with current assumptions on phrase structure.

The assumption of the lexical–functional distinction, implicit in the literature since Grimshaw (1991), leads us to attribute lexical status to an element with selectional properties. We therefore take Q in (55) to be a lexical category that selects a full extended projection, namely, the noun phrase marked as DP. This was already proposed in Giusti (1993). Being a lexical head, Q first projects its argument structure, then projects its own functional structure, which is much more reduced than that of a full noun phrase.

In this section we support the claim that existential Qs are diadic elements that select two complements: a quantitative DP to which they assign partitive Case, and a partitive PP. Distributive Qs select the same two complements and, contrary to existential Qs, they also select a distributive Operator (OP). Universal quantifiers only select a DP and do not assign Case to it.

In section 3.1, the partitive PP, introduced by di in Italian, is contrasted with an adjunct partitive PP that can also be introduced by di in certain cases but is normally introduced by tra/fra (‘among’). In section 3.2, the quantitative DP is shown to be the source of quantitative ne. Since quantitative ne is obligatory in some cases, we conclude that its source position is the internal argument of Q, which is always projected in the structure. In section 3.3, we see the structure of the three classes of quantifiers and how it can derive many of the phenomena discussed above. In section 3.4, we discuss ‘intransitive’ quantifiers such as qualcuno (‘someone’) and qualcosa (‘something’).

We assume a version of the Uniformity of Theta Assignment Hypothesis of Baker (1988a: 46) according to which, when a lexical item is shown to select an argument, the null hypothesis (and in fact the only available one) is that this argument is always projected in the structure. 12 The line of hypothesis followed here is that if there are reasons to believe that a quantifier selects a constituent, this constituent is always projected in the structure, even if non-overt. This allows us to explain a number of apparently unrelated facts.

subsection.heading: 3.1 The partitive PP and other partitive phrases
subsection.p: As we have seen in section 2.1.2, the literature in the late 1970s established that the quantitative noun phrase and the partitive prepositional phrase are different constituents. The evidence was based on the following observations. The two constituents behave differently with respect to the movement of the noun phrase of various kinds (22), (24), and (25), cannot be coordinated (26), and have different semantics (28). Furthermore, the presence of the partitive PP is bound to the presence of a quantifier, as shown in (34).

For Italian, Cardinaletti and Giusti (1992) show that the two phrases embedded under Q are not mutually exclusive, but can co-occur when the DP is realized by a noun (phrase) (96a) and by the clitic pronoun ne (96b) (see (31) and (33) for French):

(96)
a. Ho letto molti libri di quelli che mi avevi consigliato.
have.1Sg read many books of those that to-me had.2Sg recommended
b. Ne ho letti molti [DP t] di quelli che mi avevi consigliato.
NE have.1Sg read many
of those that to-me had.2Sg recommended

The null hypothesis concerning the quantitative DP is that it also occurs when the noun is non-overt, as in (97). Following Cardinaletti and Giusti (1992), we propose that (97) contains a null DP. In this way, the only difference between (97) and (96b) would be the different licensing procedure of the empty category.

(97)
Molti [DP e] di quelli che mi avevi consigliato erano interessanti.
many
of those that to-me had.2Sg recommended were interesting

The null hypothesis concerning the partitive PP is that it occupies one and the same position in (96), where it co-occurs with other nominal material (libri/ne), and in (97), where it does not. The partitive PP is selected by the quantifier and is not a complement of the noun phrase (contra Jackendoff's 1977 structure (29) above, and Abney's 1987 structure (50)), as has been argued in the discussion on (51–52). Italian left-dislocation constructions provide clear cases supporting this claim. Cinque (1991) shows that a PP such as in medicina in (98a) is a complement of N, since it cannot be used predicatively (98b). In (98c, d) it is shown that this PP must be dislocated together with the noun:

(98)
a. Conosco due studenti in medicina.
[I] know two students in medicine
b. *Questi due studenti sono in medicina.
these two students are in medicine
c. Di studenti in medicina, ne conosco due.
of students in medicine, NE know.1Sg two
d. *Di studenti ne conosco due in medicina.
of students NE know.1Sg two in medicine
The partitive PP behaves in the opposite way, suggesting that it is not a complement of N:

(99)
a. Ho visto due studenti di quelli del tuo corso.
have.1Sg seen two students of those of-the your class
b. Di studenti, ne ho visti due di quelli del tuo corso.
of students NE have.1Sg seen two of those of-the your class
c. *Di studenti di quelli del tuo corso ne ho visti due.

We also exclude that the partitive PP is (optionally) adjoined to the noun phrase. At least in Italian, the partitive PP cannot appear with noun phrases of any type. As shown in (100), it cannot occur with definite and universally quantified DPs: 13

(100)
a. *I libri di quelli che mi avevi consigliato.
b. *Tutti i libri di quelli che mi avevi consigliato.
all the books of those that [you] to-me had recommended
An optional, adjunct, partitive exists and is introduced by the preposition tra/fra (‘among’), as shown in (101). It is compatible with all kinds of DPs, including quantified constructions:

(101)
a. Ho letto solo questi libri di linguistica tra/fra quelli che mi avevi consigliato.
have.1Sg read only these books of linguistics among those that [you] to-me had recommended
b. Tutti i libri di linguistica tra/fra quelli che mi avevi consigliato mi sono piaciuti.
all the books of linguistics among those that [you] to-me had recommended to-me pleased
c. Ho letto molti libri di linguistica tra/fra quelli che mi avevi consigliato.
have.1Sg read many books of linguistics among those that [you] to-me had recommended
The adjunct partitive, introduced by tra/fra or even di, can appear in sentence-initial position. Also in this case, it is compatible with all kinds of DPs.

(102)
a. Tra/fra i libri di linguistica, ho letto quelli che mi avevi consigliato.
among the books of linguistics, [I] have read those that [you] to-me had recommended
b. Di (quei) libri, ho letto solo questi.
of (those) books have.1Sg read only these

The adjunct partitive PP can co-occur with the selected partitive PP, showing that it is a different kind of constituent (103). Crucially, the adjunct partitive can only be introduced by tra/fra and not by di if it is adjacent to the noun phrase (104):

(103)
a. Fra i libri di storia in programma, ne ho letti
among the books of history in the syllabus, NE have.1Sg read
[molti di quelli che avevi consigliato].
many of those that [you] had recommended
b. Dei libri di storia in programma, ne ho letti
of the books of history in the syllabus, NE have.1Sg read
[molti di quelli che avevi consigliato].
many of those that [you] had recommended

(104)
a. Ho letto molti libri di storia di quelli che mi avevi
have.1Sg read many books of history of those that to-me had.2Sg
consigliato tra quelli in programma
recommended, among those in the syllabus.
b. *Ho letto molti libri di storia di quelli che mi avevi consigliato di quelli in programma.

As noticed by Milner (1978b) for French and by Cardinaletti and Giusti (1992) for Italian, the selected partitive PP and the quantitative DP must contain the same lexical noun. In fact, while (105a) is marginal due to the redundancy of the information conveyed, (105b) is ruled out, even if it is not redundant at all, and clearly contrasts with the synonymous (106), where the adjunct partitive PP occurs:

(105)
a. Ho letto molti libri dei libri della biblioteca.
have.1Sg read many books of the books in the library
b. *Ho letto molti romanzi dei libri della biblioteca.
have.1Sg read many novels of the books in the library

(106)
a. Ho letto molti romanzi tra i libri della biblioteca.
have.1Sg read many novels among the books of-the library
b. Dei/tra i libri della biblioteca, ho letto molti romanzi.
of/among the books of-the library, have.1Sg read many novels.
We call this property the non-distinctness requirement and discuss it in section 3.3.4.

Up to now, we have established that the partitive PP is selected by the quantifier, it is different both from an adjunct partitive PP that can occur with any kind of noun phrase and in left-dislocation structure, and from the quantitative DP, which is also an argument of the quantifier.

The partitive PP refers to the set out of which the quantifier picks its restriction, which is a subset of it (see Cresti 2003: 83). For universal quantifiers the set and the subset coincide, and this is why no partitive PP is selected by universal tutti in (100b), by universal entrambi in (107a), and by the coordinated Q tutti e due (lit., ‘all and two’) in (107b), which can only take a definite DP (108).

(107)
a. *Entrambi dei ragazzi sono arrivati.
both of the boys have arrived
b. *Tutti e due dei ragazzi sono arrivati.
all and two of the boys have arrived

(108)
a. Entrambi i ragazzi sono arrivati.
both the boys have arrived
b. Tutti e due i ragazzi sono arrivati.
all and two the boys have arrived

As is clear from the gloss of (107), English does not have this phenomenon. There are two ways of interpreting the contrast between Italian and English. One is to attribute different (unpredictable) argument structures to quantifiers across languages; the other, to propose that an of phrase in English is ambiguous between the selected partitive PP and the adjunct partitive PP (often introduced by tra/fra but also introduced by di in Italian left-dislocation constructions, cf. (102b) and (103b)). We believe that the second way is more in the spirit of the generative enterprise. We therefore propose that the PP in all of the boys and both of the boys is an adjunct.

subsection.heading: 3.2 The quantitative DP
subsection.p: The quantitative DP realizes the restriction of the existential quantifier. We now show that it is always projected and, if empty, it is subject to licensing conditions.

In the discussion of (35–37) we observed that extraction of ne can take place from internal argument positions, while it is impossible from other positions. The syntax of ne, therefore, provides an excellent test to distinguish between internal and external argument positions. In (35–37), it was also shown that where ne is not allowed, an empty category is found. However, the interpretation of that empty category is bound to some requirements discussed in Cardinaletti and Giusti (1992) and reviewed here.
In preverbal subject position, the empty category can refer to any kind of noun:

(109)
a. Tre/molte settimane passano rapidamente.
three/many weeks elapse rapidly
b. Tre/molte [e] passano rapidamente.
three/many elapse rapidly

(110)
a. Tre/molti ragazzi hanno telefonato ieri.
three/many boys have telephoned yesterday
b. Tre/molti [e] hanno telefonato ieri.
three/many have telephoned yesterday

Rephrasing Belletti and Rizzi's proposal (see section 2.2), Cardinaletti and Giusti (1992) analyze the occurrence of the empty category in terms of the licensing conditions of Rizzi (1986a): an empty category must be formally licensed (i.e., governed by a proper head) and identified (i.e., its feature content must be recovered). The empty category embedded in a quantified noun phrase, pro, is always formally licensed by the quantifier. As for the identification requirement, the quantifier does not carry all the features necessary for a referential interpretation of pro, since it displays number and gender but crucially not person features. The empty category can be identified either by the quantitative clitic when c-commanded by it, as in (36b), or by the quantifier if it is co-indexed with an element that provides it with person features. We take this element to be AgrS for quantified noun phrases in subject position, (109b−110b).

In (109–110), we observe that in preverbal subject position cardinals and quantifiers give similar results. If we contrast (109–110) with (111), however, we observe that an empty category in the postverbal subject position is only allowed with quantifiers that display overt agreement for number and gender features, namely existential quantifiers such as molti, uno, and una, but not cardinals such as tre. 14

(111)
a. Ieri hanno telefonato tre / molti ragazzi.
yesterday have telephoned three / many boys
b. Ieri hanno telefonato *?tre/molti [e].
c. Ieri ha telefonato uno
/ una
[e].
yesterday has telephoned one-Masc.Sg / one-Fem.Sg

Since in postverbal subject position the quantifier would not be enriched with phi-features, the empty category gets an arbitrary interpretation, limited to human beings (cf. Rizzi 1986a; Cinque 1988: n. 36). This explains the contrast in (112). Similarly, (113b) can only mean that some human beings make the nests and the sentence is marked as infelicitous. 15 In (113c) we see that the prenominal subject position is acceptable, as expected, given (109b) above:

(112)
a. Hanno telefonato molti [e].
have telephoned many [people]
b. *Hanno abbaiato molti [e].
have barked many [dogs]

(113)
a. (Questo tipo di nido), lo fanno molti uccelli migratori.
(this kind of nest), it make many migrating birds
b. #(Questo tipo di nido), lo fanno molti [e].
c. Molti [e] fanno questo tipo di nido.
many do this type of nest
The same restriction holds for quantifiers in object position:

(114)
a. Ieri ho incontrato molti [e] per la strada.
yesterday have.1Sg met many [people] on my way
b. *Ieri ho letto molti [e] in biblioteca.
yesterday have.1Sg read many [things] in the library

Another argument in favor of the assumption that the internal argument of Q is always present is the observation that Q not always agrees for number (115a, b) and/or person (115c) with the following PP:

(115)
a. Una [e] delle ragazze pensa che . . .
one.Fem.Sg
of-the girls thinks that
b. Uno [e] di noi pensa che . . .
one.Masc.Sg
of us thinks that
c. Molti [e] di noi pensano che . . .
many
of us think that

Number and person are syntactic features that are structurally realized as functional heads external to the lexical NP (Ritter 1991). While the lexical NP must be non-distinct in the DP and the PP arguments of Q (cf. sections 3.1 and 3.3.4), the functional structure associated to them can be different. Notice that the features of the whole quantified noun phrase in (115) are those of the quantitative DP (third person features). The verb never agrees with the partitive PP, as shown in the ungrammatical cases in (116):

(116)
a. *Una [e] delle ragazze pensano che . . .
one.Fem.Sg
of-the girls think.3Pl
b. *Uno [e] di noi pensiamo che . . .
one.Masc.Sg
of us think.1Pl that
c. *Molti [e] di noi pensiamo che . . .
many
of us think.1Pl that
The internal argument of a distributive quantifier is always third person singular:

(117)
a. Ciascuna ragazza pensa / *pensano che . . .
each.Fem.Sg girl thinks / think.3Pl that
b. Ciascuna [e] delle ragazze pensa / *pensano che . . .
each.Fem.Sg
of-the girls thinks / think.3Pl that
c. Ciascuna [e] di noi pensa / *pensiamo che . . .
each.Fem.Sg
of us thinks / think.1Pl that

In (117a), the internal argument of the quantifier is overt, its features are third person singular, agreeing with the features on the quantifier. In (117b, c), the internal argument of the quantifier is covert and the partitive PP is realized. Since ciascuno can only take countable nouns, and ragazze is such a noun, the partitive PP is necessarily plural. The predicate agrees with the quantifier (and the covert DP), which is singular.

The argument of a universal quantifier such as tutti can have first and second person features, as in tutti noi/voi. As expected, an empty pronoun in the complement of a universal quantifier can also have these features, as in (118).

(118)
a. Tutti/Tutte [e] pensiamo che . . .
all.Masc/all.Fem think.1Pl that . . .
b. Entrambi/Entrambe [e] pensiamo che . . .
both.Masc/both.Fem think.1Pl that . . .

The first and second person features are licensed by agreement with the verb. Person agreement also takes place in postverbal subject position. Sentence (119b) is felicitous, contrasting with (113b) above. (120) is felicitous in a context in which birds can speak in first person (plural):

(119)
a. (Questo tipo di nido), lo fanno tutti gli uccelli migratori.
(this kind of nest) it make all the migrating birds
b. (Questo tipo di nido), lo fanno tutti.
(this kind of nest), it make.3Pl all
c. Tutti fanno questo tipo di nido.
all make.3Pl this kind of nest

(120)
(Questo tipo di nido), lo facciamo tutti.
(this kind of nest) it make.1Pl all
We all make this kind of nest
Notice that (119b) and (120) can also be analyzed as a floating construction, with the quantifier tutti being left in place by movement of its complement pro to IP-subject position.

In other syntactic positions where neither agreement with the predicate nor floating takes place, such as the object position, universal quantifiers, on a par with existential quantifiers, can co-occur only with an arbitrary pro with third person [human] features, as in (121a). Sentences (121b) and (121c) are infelicitous due to the fact that a [+human] interpretation of the empty category is incompatible with the verbs vendere and riflettere.

(121)
a. Ho visto tutti [e] per la strada.
have.1Sg seen all on the street
b. #Ho venduto tutti [e].
have.1Sg sold all
c. #Ho riflettuto su tutti [e].
have.1Sg thought about all
In conclusion, interpretive considerations lead us to assume that the internal argument of the quantifier is the DP, not the PP.

The different interpretations that arise in the presence and absence of ne in (35–37) and (109–114) can be captured only if a different empty category is assumed. The trace of ne can resume any kind of noun phrase. The preverbal subject position allows the licensing of a null subject in Italian that can resume any kind of noun phrase. In other positions, Italian only allows the human reference of arbitrary pro. In section 4 we give other reasons to suppose that quantitative ne is never the clitic counterpart of the partitive PP di loro.

subsection.heading: 3.3 A bare phrase structure for QP
subsection.p: Up to now we have established that all quantifiers select a quantitative DP that realizes their restriction, and that some quantifiers also select a partitive PP that realizes the set out of which such a restriction is picked.

As for existential quantifiers, this was already represented in structure (55). However, (55) is incompatible with recent approaches to phrase structure, such as the bare phrase structure hypothesis of Chomsky (1995c) and the anti-symmetry hypothesis of Kayne (1994). In this line of research, (55) can be rephrased as follows. Starting with the QP structure in (122a), the head Q and the DP are raised to a projection above QP which we call AgrQP (122b). In [Spec, AgrQP], the DP checks Case and phi-features. The head Q is further raised to F, as shown in (122c):

(122)
a.
[QP PP [Q′ Q DP]]
b.
[AgrQP DP Q [QP PP [Q′ Q DP]]]
c. [FP [F′ Q [AgrQP DP Q
[QP PP [Q′ Q DP]]]]]

The same structure and derivation hold for distributive quantifiers such as ogni/ognuno and ciascun/ciascuno (‘each’). In addition to the DP and the PP, distributive quantifiers select a distributive operator (OP), which we take to be directly merged in [Spec, FP] for the sake of simplicity: 16

(123)
a.
[QP PP [Q′ Q DP]]
b.
[AgrQP DP Q [QP PP [Q′ Q DP]]]
c. [FP OP [F′ Q [AgrQP DP Q
[QP PP [Q′ Q DP]]]]]

In the discussion of (100) we observed that universal quantifiers do not select a partitive PP. The initial structure is (124a). To capture the fact that with these quantifiers the restriction coincides with the set, we propose that the DP moves to [Spec, QP], which is the locus of the projection of the set, as in (124b).
