The quantifier also moves to AgrQP for checking reasons. In (124c), the DP moves to [Spec, AgrQP] in order to check phi-features, and the head Q is further raised to F.

(124)
a.
[QP
[Q′ Q DP]]
b.
[AgrQP
Q [QP DP [Q′ Q DP]]]
c. [FP [F′ Q [AgrQP
DP Q
[QP DP
[Q′ Q DP]]]]]
We now consider in detail the checking properties of these parallel structures and some of their consequences.

subsection.heading: 3.3.1 Partitive case
subsection.p: In configurations (122b) and (123b), the DP complement of existential and distributive quantifiers checks partitive case in [Spec, AgrQP]. Two observations support this proposal: the genitive morphology on the clitic that binds the quantitative DP (Italian ne, French en) and the preposition di/de, generally realizing genitive case, which occurs with the quantitative DP in certain cases (see section 3.3.3). Consider an existential quantifier in (125).

(125)
Di ragazzi, ne ho visti molti.
of boys, NE have.1Sg seen many

Partitive ne does not surface with distributive quantifiers. In this case, however, we maintain the assignment of partitive case by the quantifier and relate the ungrammaticality of (126) to the presence of the distributive OP(erator) in [Spec, FP], which blocks extraction of the quantitative DP:

(126)
a. *Ne ho visti/o ogni/ognuno/ciascuno.
NE have.1Sg seen each
b. *Di ragazzi (ne) ho visto ognuno/ciascuno.
of boys NE have.1Sg seen each

Partitive case does not surface with universal quantifiers either. These quantifiers never co-occur with the clitic pronoun ne, neither does their DP complement ever appear with the preposition di, as shown in (127). 17

(127)
a. *Ne ho visti tutti.
NE have.1Sg seen all
b. *Di ragazzi (ne) ho visto/i tutti.
of boys NE have.1Sg seen all

We interpret the inability to assign partitive as the result of the semantics of universal quantifiers that do not have the function to relate a subset to a set. As a matter of fact, the subset expressed by the restriction and the set out of which the restriction is picked coincide for universal quantifiers.

Since the quantifier is traditionally considered as a modifier of the noun phrase, the proposal that it assigns Case is not straightforward and deserves some further discussion. 18 In our proposal, the quantifier is assumed to be a lexical head with its own selectional features. From this point of view, nothing prevents it from assigning Case to its complement DP.

It has often been noticed in the literature that in some languages it is possible to find a correlation between definiteness/specificity and Case. Belletti (1988), for example, claims that transitive and unaccusative verbs can assign partitive case to their internal argument position, provided that the internal argument is indefinite. Enç (1991) argues that in Turkish, specificity is marked on noun phrases in object position with accusative case, while non-specific noun phrases in object position have no case marking at all. Kornfilt (1996) argues that in Turkish some instances of ablative case can be analyzed as the realization of (abstract) partitive case. Furthermore, Kiparsky (1998) also shows that (in)definiteness of the arguments and aspect of the predicate are strictly related and the assignment of a particular case marking is often only one side of the strategy, the other side being the surfacing of an aspect marker on the predicate.

Our proposal that the apparent genitive case morphology that we find on the quantitative DP in different constructions realizes partitive case is consistent with this line of research. We do not enter the discussion here whether partitive is a structural or an inherent Case (see Belletti 1988). However, in our proposal partitive case is assigned structurally by quantifiers of the existential and distributive class, and not by other quantifiers. We keep to the observation that (abstract) partitive case is universally found across languages and realized in various ways according to the morphological systems of noun phrases and even verb phrases in different languages.

subsection.heading: 3.3.2 Agreement
subsection.p: Case checking and phi-feature checking often go together, as is the case for subject DPs. While checking partitive case, the quantitative DP agrees with the quantifier, which is endowed with number and gender features. This results in the three patterns in (128):

As a matter of fact, agreement between the quantifier and its internal argument is not overt in all contexts. In the Hebrew examples in (56a) and (57a) the quantifier is invariable when it precedes its complement. But when the complement is moved out, it agrees with it, as in (56b) and (57b).
A different situation is provided by the Turkish examples in (129), where the quantitative DP has no number features. 19

(129)
a. Iki kιz-ι tanιyordum.
two girl-Acc knew.1Sg
b. Iki kιz tanιyordum.
two girl knew.1Sg
‘I knew two girls.’

Enç (1991) shows that in Turkish, the quantifier can take a specific DP in accusative (129a) or a non-specific DP marked with no case morphology (129b). In neither case the number of the quantifier percolates onto the DP. The reference of the DP is plural nonetheless, as shown in the left-dislocated structure (130):

(130)
Kιz lar dan iki sin i tanιyordum.
girl Pl Abl two Agr Acc knew.1Sg
Notice that in (130) the quantifier displays case and agreement morphology since its internal argument is non-overt, parallel to Hebrew (56b) and (57b) above.

subsection.heading: 3.3.3 Partitive case realized by di/de
subsection.p: In French, the preposition de surfaces with a certain class of quantifiers including beaucoup, peu, and combien, which are invariable:

(131)
a. J’ai vu beaucoup *(de) filles.
I have seen many of girls
b. J’ai vu plusieurs (*de) filles.
I have seen many (*of) girls

We suggest that quantifiers like beaucoup, having no inflectional morphology, cannot enter an agreement relation with the quantitative DP. The partitive case checked by the DP in [Spec, AgrP] must be realized by the preposition de (for a different analysis, see Battye 1987).

In the examples at (63) we saw an instance of non-agreeing quantifiers in English, which looks like an exception to condition (128a). The lack of agreement in these cases is reminiscent of the cases of beaucoup in (131). These quite exceptional English cases can be analyzed in a way similar to French beaucoup. Although in Italian we do not have invariable quantifiers like beaucoup, we observe a comparable situation in (132). The preposition di, which optionally occurs with the predicative adjectives stranded by ne cliticization, as in (132a) (cf. section 4.2), becomes obligatory with a non-overt quantifier, as in (132b):

(132)
a. Ne conosco due (di) simpatici.
NE know.1Sg two (of) nice
a. Ne conosco Ø *(di) simpatici.
NE know.1Sg [some] (of) nice

The presence of the overt quantifier makes the case visible in (132a), where di is optional. The non-overt quantifier, on the contrary, cannot make the partitive case visible in (132b), where di is required.
An empty quantifier can also be assumed in the case of the so-called partitive determiner in Italian and French (see Casadio 1995 and Chierchia 1997a):

(133)
a. Ho letto Ø dei libri.
b. J’ai lu Ø des livres.
I have read of-the books
‘I read some books.’

The fact that the quantifier is empty makes it necessary for partitive case to be spelled out as di/de. Di/de take the agreeing form dei/des in order to spell-out all phi-features. This is not necessary in other contexts, where the presence of the clitic ne guarantees that phi-features are spelled out, as testified by agreement on the past participle (cf. Di/*dei ragazzi, ne ho visti ‘of/*of-the boys NE have.1Sg seen’).
Another case in which the preposition di/de is required in Italian and French is when the quantitative DP is left- or right-dislocated. 20

(134)
a. Di ragazzi, ne ho visti molti.
b.
Ne ho visti molti, di ragazzi.
of boys, NE have.1Sg seen many

(135)
a. De filles, j’en ai vu plusieures.
b.
J’en ai vu plusieures, de filles.
of girls, NE have.1Sg seen many

In (134) and (135) the quantifier is present but the relation to the left-dislocated DP is not local. This is the reasons for the obligatory insertion of di/de. As above, the preposition makes partitive Case visible.

subsection.heading: 3.3.4 The lexical non-distinctness requirement on DP and PP
subsection.p: In the discussion at (105) we observed that the lexical N in the quantitative DP is non-distinct from the lexical N in the partitive PP. We took this to be the result of the fact that the DP realizes the restriction (variable) of the quantifier and the PP realizes the set (range) out of which this restriction is picked. The lexical items that realize the restriction and the set must be lexically identical for reasons that are not logically necessary since the same requirement does not hold for adjunct partitive PPs (cf. (106)).

(136)
a. Ho letto molti libri
dei libri
che mi avevi consigliato.
b. *Ho letto molti romanzi
dei libri
che mi avevi consigliato.
have.1Sg read many books/*novels of-the books that to-me had.2Sg recommended

The fact that this property appears quite generally across languages leads us to assume that the lexical non-distinctness requirement is a UG principle. According to this requirement, the variable and the range must be non-distinct in their lexical content, which we take to be structurally realized at the NP-level. The variable and the range can differ in their functional structure, where phi-features (basically number), Case, and referential features are projected. As for number features, this has been shown in (115) and (116). As for Case features, we have claimed that the quantitative DP checks Case according to the properties of the quantifier. The partitive PP is selected by the quantifier, but it receives an oblique case assigned by the preposition. As for the referential properties, the variable does not refer, by definition, while the set, which is generally definite, 21 can be D-linked or non-D-linked in the sense of Pesetsky (1987a).

The non-distinctness requirement is a particular kind of co-indexing, which certainly plays a role in the licensing of silent elements in DPs and PPs. 22 We now consider some possible cases of empty categories in quantified noun phrases. When the DP is null and the PP is overt, the NP inside DP is interpreted as non-distinct from the overt NP inside the PP (libro); the number is recovered by agreement with the quantifier (plural in (137a), singular in (137b)); (partitive) case is independently assigned by the quantifier: 23

(137)
a. molti [e] dei libri/ di quei libri
many
of-the books/ of those books
b. uno [e] dei libri/ di quei libri
one
of those books/ of those books

When the DP is overt and the PP is null, the NP inside the PP is interpreted as non-distinct from the NP inside the DP. The number is plural for count nouns or singular for mass nouns, due to the partitive constraint or any version of it (see n. 21). The referential properties of the PP must be either recovered from the context (many books can mean ‘many books among those that are relevant in the context’), or left undetermined (many books can mean ‘many books in general’). In the former case, we take the empty partitive PP to be D-linked. In the latter case, we take the empty partitive PP to be non-D-linked.

When both the DP and the PP are null, neither NP is realized and the lexical features must be recovered from the context. As a consequence, the interpretation is different depending on the position occupied by the quantified noun phrase, as also observed in section 3.2. When the QP occupies the subject position, it agrees with the predicate. IP-agreement in Italian allows a null pronoun pro. The partitive PP also contains a pro with the same features; it can be D-linked or not.

(138)
a. Molti [e] [e] sono troppo costosi.
many
are too expensive
b. Molte [e] [e] non sanno che . . .
many-Fem.Pl
don't know that . . .

In (138a) we see the case of molti inflected for masculine plural features. A masculine plural referent must be available from the context. Take, for example, libri (‘books’). In (138b) a feminine plural referent must be available from the context, e.g., ragazze (‘girls’).

When the QP occupies the object position, as in (139), as well as the postverbal subject position seen in (111–113), the interpretation is limited to human beings. This is due to the fact that in these positions the features of the NP cannot be recovered in Italian and the only possible feature to be attributed to pro is the arbitrary human feature (see section 3.2).

(139)
a. Ieri ho incontrato molti [e] [e] per la strada.
yesterday have.1Sg met many [people]
on the street
b. *Ieri ho letto molti [e] [e] in biblioteca.
yesterday have.1Sg read many [things]
in the library
The arbitrary feature is incompatible with D-linking, and the PP can be interpreted only as non-D-linked.

Let us now consider the cases in which only the NP inside the PP is null, but the functional features of either complement are realized. When the DP is overt, the phrase embedded in the partitive PP usually has an empty NP. It can contain a demonstrative and can be modified by a relative clause; in all cases the NP is non-distinct from the NP in the restriction, (140a). If it contains a lexical NP, the result is a redundant construction (140b) (cf. (105)).

(140)
a. molti libri di quelli [e] che mi hai consigliato
many books of those that to-me have.2Sg recommended
b. #molti libri dei libri che mi hai consigliato
many books of-the books that [you] to-me have.2Sg recommended

When the DP is realized by ne, the partitive PP always contains a pronoun: a demonstrative pronoun, such as quelli in (141a) and questi in (141b), a focused personal pronoun such as loro in (141c), or a relative pronoun such as cui in (141d) (also see French (33b, c)). 24

(141)
a. Ne ho letti molti di quelli (che mi hai consigliato).
NE have.1Sg read many of those (that to-me have.2Sg recommended)
b. Ne ho letti molti di questi qui.
NE have.1Sg read many of these here
c. Ne ho visti molti di LORO, non di voi.
NE have.1Sg seen many of them, not of you
d. Quei libri di linguistica, di cui Mario ne ha letti molti, erano piuttosto interessanti.
those books of linguistics, of which Mario NE has read many, were very interesting

The focus on the personal pronoun in (141c) guarantees that the PP di LORO is not right-dislocated. Right dislocation of the partitive PP is always possible. In that case the PP inside the QP structure is simply empty and interpreted with the features of the right-dislocated overt PP. 25
When the DP is realized by ne, the PP cannot contain a lexical NP. The lexical NP in (142) is excluded by principle C of Binding Theory, since it is co-indexed with and c-commanded by ne:

(142)
a. *Ne ho letti molti dei libri (che mi hai consigliato).
b. *Ne ho letti molti di quei libri (che mi hai consigliato).
NE have.1Sg read many of-the/of those books (that to-me have.2Sg advised)

In conclusion, the different realization and interpretations of the quantified phrases in (137–142) derive straightforwardly from the assumption that the two arguments of the quantifier are always projected and from the assumption of the non-distinctness requirement, which allows the interpretation of empty elements through a partial co-indexing.

subsection.heading: 3.3.5 Extraction out of QP
subsection.p: One of the crucial reasons for assuming that Q is a head external to the DP is the fact that these two elements can occur discontinuously, and that the DP appears to move out of a specifier of the Q projection. We observed some cases across languages in (56–62). The configuration in (122) provides such a Specifier position in [Spec, FP], as shown in (122d). The DP can further move out of the FP, as in (122e):

(122)
d. [FP DP [F′ Q [AgrQP DP [Q [QP (PP) [Q′ Q DP]]]]]]
e. DP . . . [FP DP [F′ Q [AgrQP DP [Q [QP (PP) [Q′ Q DP]]]]]]

The trigger of overt DP-movement to and through [Spec, FP] is different across languages. It can be movement to the subject position in search of Case. This can take place only out of universal quantifiers, which do not assign Case to their complement DP. The complement of existential and distributive quantifiers cannot move to a nominative-case-assignment position, since it checks partitive case QP-internally (see section 3.3.1). This explains the contrasts in (143): 26

(143)
a. The boys have all eaten a sandwich.
b. I ragazzi hanno tutti mangiato un panino.
c. *Boys have many eaten a sandwich.
d. *Ragazzi hanno molti mangiato un panino.
e. *Boy has each eaten a sandwich.
f. *Ragazzo ha ciascuno mangiato un panino.
The ungrammaticality of (143d) cannot be reduced to the Italian property of not allowing indefinite subjects in preverbal subject position, since the same pattern is found in English (143c).

We take [Spec, FP] to be the intermediate position for movement out of the quantified phrase. Like the derivation of all other clitic pronouns, ne-cliticization can be decomposed into two steps: XP movement followed by X0-movement (Sportiche 1990; Cardinaletti and Starke 1999: section 6.3). Ne is first moved as an XP (DP) to the specifier of AgrQP. In so doing, ne, which does not have intrinsic phi-features, receives the phi-features of the quantifier (see Belletti and Rizzi 1996b: 18) (for the agreement between Q and the quantitative DP, see sections 3.2 and 3.3.2 above). 27 Ne further moves through [Spec, FP] and through the specifier of the past participle, which triggers agreement on the past participle (see (176a)) (see Kayne 1989a).

Clitic extraction is possible only out of universal quantifiers, which do not assign Case but agree with their complement for phi-features, and existential quantifiers, which assign partitive case to their complement and agree for phi-features. The complement of the distributive quantifier cannot be extracted because of the blocking effect of the distributive operator in [Spec, FP] (see section 3.3.1).

(144)
a. Li ho mangiati tutti.
them have.1Sg eaten all
b. Ne ho mangiati molti
NE have.1Sg eaten many
c. *Lo/*Ne ho mangiato ciascuno
it/NE have.1Sg eaten each

In conclusion, [Spec, FP] is a sort of A′-position that functions as an escape hatch for extractions out of quantified noun phrases and hosts material relevant for interpretive procedures which are supposed to take place at LF. 28

subsection.heading: 3.4 ‘Intransitive’ quantifiers
subsection.p: Quantified noun phrases can be ‘pronominal’ in two ways. Quantifiers can embed a covert DP, provided that it is licensed somehow (see section 3.3.4). A second type of ‘pronominal’ quantifier is that which never appears with a DP, such as something, somebody in English. In section 2.3.1 we argued against an analysis of the morphemes -thing and -body as Ns that incorporate to D in the syntax. In our framework, an analysis in terms of N to Q is to be excluded for the same reasons. In the spirit of what we have proposed so far, we consider these quantifiers as ‘intransitive’, i.e., as not projecting any argument at all, on a par with (personal) pronouns. The only way these quantifiers can be modified is through predication. This analysis captures the following facts.

In English, the adjectives that modify intransitive quantifiers appear postnominally (145a, b) and can only be those that can appear in predicative position (cf. the contrast between (145a, b) and (145c, d)). Furthermore, intransitive quantifiers combine with else, which cannot occur as a prenominal adjective and cannot combine with other, which appears prenominally. See the paradigm in (146).

(145)
a. I met somebody nice.
b. I bought something good.
c. *I met somebody principal/main.
d. *I must do something principal/main.

(146)
a. I saw somebody/something else.
b. *I saw somebody/something other.
c. I saw some other boy/book.
d. *I saw some else boy/book.

Similar arguments can be built for Italian. The adjectives that appear with intransitive Qs can only be those that appear in predicative position (see (147a, b) and (147c); cf. also (47)). Furthermore, they are preceded by di, as are predicative adjectives ‘floated’ from quantified noun phrases with a bare Q (cf. section 3.3.3, example (132)).

(147)
a. Ho incontrato qualcuno di importante.
have.1Sg met someone of important
b. Ho mangiato qualcosa di buono.
have.1Sg eaten something of good
c. *Ho visto qualcuno/qualcosa di principale.
have.1Sg seen someone/something of principal

Notice that the occurrence of di is obligatory with qualcosa (compare (147b) with *Ho mangiato qualcosa buono), but it is optional with qualcuno (compare (147a) with Ho incontrato qualcuno importante). (We thank Roberto Zamparelli for pointing this out to us.) This is because intransitive qualcuno (but not qualcosa) is homophonous with the allomorph qualcuno of the quantifier qualche, which is found when the argument of the quantifier qualche is realized by the clitic pronoun ne or by a null DP:

(148)
a. Ho letto qualche libro.
have.1Sg read some book
b. Ne ho letto qualcuno [t] (di quelli).
NE have.1Sg read some
(of those)
c. Ho letto qualcuno [e] di quei libri.
have.1Sg read some
of those books

The two instances of qualcuno should be kept separate. Intransitive qualcuno can only have [+human] referents (on a par with English somebody and someone), while the allomorph qualcuno of qualche is also compatible with [−human] referents, such as book in (148b, c).

The ambiguous status of qualcuno can explain the distribution of di in front of predicative adjectives. When di on the adjective is present, as in (147a), we have an instance of the intransitive quantifier qualcuno; when di on the adjective is absent, we have an instance of the quantifier qualche with an empty DP, as in (148c). The two structures are provided in (149):

(149)
a. Ho incontrato qualcuno di importante.
have.1Sg met someone of important
b. Ho incontrato qualcuno [e]
importante.
have.1Sg met someone
important

subsection.heading: 3.5 Conclusions
subsection.p: In this section we have offered a proposal that can capture the various syntactic phenomena that arise with quantified constructions across languages by refining Cardinaletti and Giusti's (1992) and Giusti's (1991a) original proposals on the structure of quantified noun phrases.

We have proposed that a quantifier Q is a lexical head that projects a QP inside which its arguments are merged. Q further projects an intermediate functional projection (AgrP) where the internal argument agrees with Q and checks partitive Case (if Q has such a property). Finally, Q projects a second functional projection (FP) whose Spec is the locus of the interpretation of the entire quantified construction as well as an escape hatch for movement out of the quantified noun phrase.

subsection.heading: 4 The syntax of quantitative clitics
subsection.p: In this section we focus on quantitative clitics. As we have done with the structure of quantified phrases earlier, we start with a presentation of various proposals that have been made in the course of the last thirty years. 29 First, we discuss whether ne is a non-maximal (N′) or a maximal category. The conclusion will be that ne is a maximal projection. Three competing analyses of this maximal projection are considered: NP, PP, and DP. We show that the latter analysis is to be preferred over the others.

subsection.heading: 4.1 Quantitative clitics as N′
subsection.p: Ruwet (1972: 49–50) and Milner (1978b: 49) are the first authors who differentiate quantitative en from prepositional en. Quantitative en cannot be extracted out of a QP occurring in subject position, while this is possible for genitive en.

(150)
a. Deux/beaucoup de cheminées sont penchées.
two/many of chimneys are leaning
b. *Deux/*beaucoup en sont penchées.
two/many EN are leaning

(151)
a. La cheminée de l’usine est penchée.
the chimney of the factory is leaning
b. La cheminée en est penchée.
Quantitative en can apparently resume both a definite and an indefinite noun phrase, while genitive en can only pronominalize a definite noun phrase (Milner 1978b: 49–50).

(152)
a. Les/des livres de Zola, j’en ai lu deux.
the/some books by Zola I EN have read two
b. Ce/*un livre de Zola, j’en ai lu la fin avec plaisir.
this/a book by Zola I EN have read the end with pleasure
On the basis of the differences between quantitative and genitive en, Milner (1978b) suggests that the former is an N′, while the latter is a maximal projection (N″).

Assuming a Simple Noun Phrase Hypothesis as in Selkirk (1977), Belletti and Rizzi (1981) treat Italian ne as an N′ as well (cf. section 2.2). Ne pronominalizes the head noun and its complements, while the quantifier remains in place.

(153)
a. Maria conosce tre racconti del nonno.
Maria knows three stories of grandpa
b. Maria ne conosce tre.
Maria NE knows three

A second argument for the N′-status of ne is discussed by Rizzi (1979) and has already been mentioned in (40). Assuming a structure like (41) where prenominal APs are under N′ and postnominal APs are under N″, Rizzi shows that prenominal adjectives cannot be stranded by ne cliticization, as shown by the contrast in (154).

(154)
a. Ho letto un lunghissimo libro.
b. Ho letto un libro lunghissimo.
have.1Sg read a very-long book
c. *Ne ho letto un lunghissimo.
d. Ne ho letto uno lunghissimo.

In (154c) the adjective must be prenominal, on a par with (154a), since in both cases the quantifier has the reduced form un. In (154d) the adjective must be analyzed as postnominal, since the quantifier displays the full form uno, which also appears when the quantifier is bare, as in Ne ho letto uno ‘[I] NE have read one’. According to Rizzi, the contrast between (154c) and (154d) can be explained by assuming that ne is an N′ and that those elements that are external to N′ can be left in place by ne-cliticization.

Rizzi's observations are confirmed by the hehavior of other kinds of adjective. While in the case of a full NP, the AP can be either prenominal or postnominal, when ne-cliticization applies only postnominal adjectives can appear. This is most apparent in the case of adjectives such as mero in (155) and certo in (156). Mero can appear only prenominally and is ungrammatical when ne-cliticization applies. Certo has a different interpretation according to the position it occupies; in the ne-construction, it only has the postnominal interpretation.

(155)
a. Si è fatta una mera illusione.
had.3SgFem a mere illusion
b. *Si è fatta una illusione mera.
c. *Se ne è fatta una mera.

(156)
a. Hanno dato una certa notizia
have.3Pl given a certain (=particular) piece of news
b. Hanno dato una notizia certa
have.3Pl given a piece of news certain (=sure)
c. Ne hanno data una certa
NE have.3Pl given one certain (=sure)

Despite the reasons seen so far, the N′-analysis of ne is not without problems. At the theoretical level, ne would represent the only instance of X′-movement. At the empirical level, this analysis encounters problems when different classes of modifiers and arguments of the noun are taken into account.

As noticed by Cinque (1991: 122), postnominal adjectives like principale cannot be stranded by ne-cliticization. The ungrammaticality of (157c) is unexpected in the analysis in (41) above, unless we assume that principale, contrary to other postnominal adjectives, is generated under N′.

(157)
a. Gianni ha due ragioni principali per non accettare quel posto.
Gianni has two reasons main to not accept that position
b. *Gianni ha due principali ragioni per non accettare quel posto.
c. *Di ragioni, Gianni ne ha due principali per non accettare quel posto.
of reasons Gianni NE has two main to not accept that position

Another problem for the N′-analysis of ne is represented by the arguments of the noun that can be left in situ under ne-cliticization. In addition to (153b) and (158), where ne stands for both the head noun and its complement, the sentences in (159) are also possible.

(158)
a. Di ritratti di mio nonno, ne possiedo due.
b. Di ritratti di Picasso, ne possiedo due.
c. Di ritratti di quel collezionista, ne possiedo due.
of pictures of my grandpa/Picasso/that collectionist NE have.1Sg two

(159)
a. Di ritratti, ne possiedo due di mio nonno.
b. Di ritratti, ne possiedo due di Picasso.
c. Di ritratti, ne possiedo due di quel collezionista.
of pictures NE have.1Sg two [e] of my grandpa/Picasso/that collectionist
As shown by Giorgi and Longobardi (1991), the arguments of the noun occupy different structural positions inside the NP depending on their theta-role.
(160) [NP Spec [N″ [N″ [N′ N0 internal argument] agent] possessor]]

The apparent possibility of leaving any argument of the noun stranded could lead us to the assumption that ne can resume any projection of N, from N0 to N″. It is theoretically undesirable that a lexical item stands for different projectional levels. More seriously, the fact that ne can stand for the head noun mars the argument built on the non-occurrence of prenominal adjectives with ne, seen above in (154), (155), and (156).

subsection.heading: 4.2 Quantitative clitics as maximal projections
subsection.p: Both problems can be solved by assuming that the quantitative clitic pronoun ne, like other clitic pronouns, binds a maximal projection. This proposal is a natural consequence of the hypothesis that quantified nominals are QPs that embed a maximal projection.

The cases in which ne seems to bind an intermediate projection of N must be analyzed otherwise. Cinque (1991) and Cardinaletti and Giusti (1992) suggest that the material left in place by ne-cliticization is a modifier of the noun phrase, occurring in a postnominal predicative position. Among adjectives, only those that can occur in predicative position can appear in ne-constructions (cf. (155) and (156)).

(161)
a. *Questa illusione è mera.
this illusion is mere
b. *Ritengo questa illusione mera.
consider.1Sg this illusion mere

(162)
a. Questa notizia è certa.
this piece of news is certain (=sure)
b. Ritengo questa notizia certa.
consider.1Sg this piece of news certain (=sure)
This solves the paradox built by the data with the adjective principale; it cannot occur with ne, as shown in (157c), nor can it appear in predicative constructions:

(163)
a. *Le due ragioni di Gianni per non accettare quel posto sono principali.
the two reasons of Gianni not to accept that position are principal
b. *Ritengo questo argomento principale.
consider.1Sg this topic principal

The same proposal should be made for the apparent arguments of the noun in (159) above. They must be considered modifiers of the noun, occurring in the postnominal predicative position. The prediction that they also enter predicative constructions is borne out.

(164)
a. Quel ritratto è di mio nonno.
b. Quel ritratto è di Picasso.
c. Quel ritratto è di quel collezionista.
that portrait is of my grandpa/Picasso/that collectionist
The complements that cannot occur as predicates are also ungrammatical with ne, as noted by Cinque (1991: 121–122).

(165)
a. *Quello studioso è del Petrarca.
that scholar is of Petrarca
b. *Quell’esperto è in microprocessori.
that expert is in microprocessors
c. *Quel ladro era di galline.
that thief was of chickens

(166)
a. *Di studiosi, ne stimano anche uno del Petrarca.
of scholars NE estimate.3Pl also one of-the Petrarca
b. *Di esperti, ne hanno assunto uno in microprocessori.
of experts NE have.3Pl hired one in microprocessors
c. *Di ladri, ne hanno preso uno di galline.
of thieves NE have.3Pl caught one of chickens

Cardinaletti and Giusti (1992) also show that a complement clause such as di risolvere il problema in (167a) cannot appear as a predicate (167b) and cannot be left stranded by ne cliticization (see (167c) vs. (167d)): 30

(167)
a. Ci sono due modi di risolvere il problema.
there are two ways to solve the problem
b. *Questo modo è di risolvere il problema.
this way is to solve the problem
c. *Di modi, ce ne sono due di risolvere il problema.
d. Di modi di risolvere il problema, ce ne sono due.
of ways to solve the problem there NE are two
In conclusion, quantitative clitics bind a maximal projection, not an N′. In what follows we discuss the categorial status of this maximal projection.

subsection.heading: 4.3 On the nature of the maximal projection bound by quantitative clitics
4.3.1 Quantitative clitics as PPs
subsection.p: Contrary to Ruwet (1972) and Milner (1978b) (see section 4.1), Kayne (1975) takes French quantitative en to be a prepositional clitic. The argument for this proposal is the fact that en, contrary to the nominal object clitics le/la/les and parallel to prepositional clitics, is invariable, as shown in (168), and does not trigger past-participle agreement, as shown in (169). 31

(168)
a. Elle le/la/les voit.
she him/her/them sees
b. Il en parle tout le temps, de sa maison/de son travail/de ses problèmes.
he EN speaks all the time of his house/of his work/of his problems
c. Paul a deux sœurs/frères; j’en ai trois.
Paul has two sisters/brothers; I EN have three

(169)
a. On l’ a mise sur la table (la fourchette).
one it has put-Fem.Sg on the table the fork
one EN has put on the table some forks
b. Il en a parlé(*e) tout le temps, de sa maison.
he EN has spoken (*Fem.Sg) all the time of his house
c. *On en a mises sur la table (des fourchettes).
one EN has put-Fem.Pl on the table some forks
d. On en a mis sur la table (des fourchettes).

Assuming that quantified noun phrases have the underlying form deux de soeurs, Kayne (1975) suggests that quantitative en pronominalizes the complement de soeurs, or more precisely, its pronominal counterpart de elles. 32

Belletti (1979: section 5.3) assumes a similar analysis for Italian ne. Ne stands for the partitive phrase introduced by di. The proposal that ne is a prepositional clitic has the advantage of unifying quantitative ne with the non-quantitative instances of ne, which stand for PPs introduced by di (170) or da (171). These PPs can be complements to verbs, nouns, and prepositions.

(170)
a. Ne ho parlato. (ne = del progetto)
NE have.1Sg spoken (NE = of-the project)
b. Ne ho comprato un ritratto. (ne = della regina)
NE have.1Sg bought a picture (NE = of-the queen)
c. Ne sono rimasto senza. (ne = sigarette)
NE am left without (NE = cigarettes)

(171)
a. Ne uscì un uomo. (ne = dalla casa)
NE came out a man (NE = from-the house)
b. Amava Maria e ne era riamato. (ne = da Maria)
loved.3SgMasc Maria and NE was loved back (NE = by Maria)
c. Ne sono finalmente fuori. (ne = da questo incubo)
NE am finally out (NE = of this nightmare)

As in French, Italian quantitative ne differs from accusative clitics (172a) and patterns with prepositional ne (172b) in that it is invariable. Example (172c) shows that ne is not specified for gender; (173) further shows that ne is invariable for number: it is compatible with both a singular and a plural left-dislocated noun phrase. 33

(172)
a. Paolo lo/la/li/le detesta.
Paolo him/her/them.Fem/them.Masc hates
b. Ne parla sempre, della sua casa/del suo lavoro/dei suoi problemi/delle sue amiche.
NE speaks.3SgMasc of his house/of his work/of his problems/of his girlfriends always
c. Paolo ha due sorelle/fratelli; io ne ho tre.
Paolo has two sisters/brothers I NE have three

(173)
a. Di libro, ne ho letto uno.
of book NE have.1Sg read one
b. Di libri, ne ho letto uno.
of books NE have.1Sg read one

If ne is a PP that stands for de elles/di loro, it pronominalizes the partitive PP complement of Q. But we have argued that en/ne binds the quantitative DP and is not the clitic counterpart of the strong pronoun de elles/di loro which only realizes the partitive PP. In what follows, we discuss more evidence to show that a PP analysis of quantitative clitics is inadequate.

subsection.heading: 4.3.2 Quantitative clitics as DPs
subsection.p: Quantitative en/ne can co-occur with the PP complement of Q (see (33) and (96b)). This is unexpected if ne is a partitive PP:

(174)
a. J’en ai lu beaucoup t
de ceux que tu m’as recommandés.
I EN have read many
of those that you to-me have advised
b. Ne ho letti molti t
di quelli che mi hai consigliato.
NE have.1Sg read many
of those that to-me have.2Sg recommended

Second, quantitative ne behaves like DPs but unlike PPs in left-dislocation structures. It obligatorily resumes a left-dislocated phrase, as happens with DPs but not with PPs, which are only optionally resumed by a clitic.

(175)
a. Di ragazzi francesi, *(ne) ho conosciuti molti.
of boys French, NE have.1Sg met many
b. I ragazzi francesi, *(li) ho conosciuti.
the boys French, them have.1Sg met
c. Di questo libro, (ne) hanno parlato molto bene.
of this book, NE have.3Sg spoken very well
d. Con Maria, (ci) ho parlato ieri.
with Maria, CI have.1Sg spoken yesterday

Third, quantitative ne triggers agreement on the past participle, on a par with object clitics and differently from prepositional clitics, including non-quantitative ne (in this respect, Italian quantitative ne differs from French en, see section 4.3.1).

(176)
a. Ne ho conosciut*o/i/e molti/e.
NE have.1Sg met-Masc.Sg/-Masc.Pl./-Fem.Pl manyMasc.Pl/many-Fem.Pl
b. Li ho conosciut*o/i.
them-Masc.Pl have.1Sg met-Masc.Sg/-Masc.Pl
c. Ne hanno parlato/*a/*i/*e molto bene.
NE have.3Pl spoken-Masc.Sg/-Fem.Sg/-Masc.Pl/-Fem.Pl. very well
d. Ci ho parlato/*a/*i/*e ieri.
with him/her/them have.1Sg spoken-Masc.Sg/-Fem.Sg/-Masc.Pl/-Fem.Pl yesterday

If accusative object clitics are DPs, the parallel behavior of (175a) and (175b) on the one hand and (176a) and (176b) on the other can be captured by suggesting that ne is a DP (Cardinaletti and Giusti 1992). In conclusion, ne is the clitic form of the quantitative DP. It is a syncretic form which stands for any number and gender, like the dative DP clitic gli in colloquial Italian, which stands for any gender and number (Gli ho parlato ieri [I] to him/to her/to them have spoken yesterday). This conclusion can be extended to French en. In this view, the contrasts in (168) and (172) are not arguments against a DP analysis of quantitative clitics.

The fact that French en does not trigger past-participle agreement (see (169)) can then no longer be considered as an argument for its PP status. It can be explained along the lines suggested by Belletti and Rizzi (1996b: 18). The difference between Italian and French with respect to past-participle agreement with quantitative clitics is the result of a parametric choice: Italian ne can contain phi-features, while French en cannot. While moving through [Spec, QP] (see n. 27), Italian ne can receive the phi-features of the quantifier, and the successive movement through the specifier of the past-participle projection triggers agreement on the past participle. The derivation of French en is the same, the only difference being that en cannot inherit the features of the quantifier while moving through [Spec, QP].

subsection.heading: 4.3.3 Quantitative clitics as NPs
subsection.p: There are, however, two respects in which ne differs from accusative and dative object clitics, namely, binding properties and co-occurrence with relative clauses. These properties have led Belletti (1993a: 115, n. 34) and Cinque (1991: n. 7) to analyze ne as an NP, not a DP. We show below that these asymmetries are only apparent, and that ne can be safely analyzed as DP on a par with the other (accusative and dative) object clitics.
Quoting Cresti (1993), Belletti observes that quantitative ne obeys principle C of Binding Theory, disallowing binding from a c-commanding DP (cf. Cresti 2003: 87).

(177)
*[Gianni e Mario]i
mi hanno chiesto di ricevernei
almeno uno prima delle undici.
Gianni and Mario to-me have.3Pl asked to meet.NE at least one before eleven

In this respect, quantitative ne differs from DP clitics (accusative and dative), which obey principle B of the Binding Theory, (178), and behaves like nonquantitative instances of ne, which are PPs and are excluded in c-command contexts; compare the contrast between (179a) and (179b). 34

(178)
a. Giannii
sostiene che Maria loi conosce.
Gianni claims that Maria him knows
b. Giannii
sostiene che Maria glii parlerà.
Gianni claims that Maria to-him will-talk

(179)
a. *Giannii
sostiene che Maria nei parla spesso.
Gianni claims that Maria NE talks often
b. Maria deve essere innamorata di Giannii
perché nei parla sempre.
Maria must be in love with Gianni because NE talks always
Notice, however, that quantitative ne is also ungrammatical in a context where it is not c-commanded by its antecedent. In this respect, (180) differs from (179b).

(180)
*Maria deve essere innamorata di [Gianni e Mario]i perché vuole ricevernei almeno uno prima delle undici.
Maria must be in love with Gianni and Mario because [she] wants to meet.NE at least one before eleven

The ungrammaticality of (180) cannot be due to a violation of Binding Theory, but only to the fact that ne cannot pronominalize a definite DP. The same explanation holds for (177). Definite DPs can only be pronominalized by the strong form di loro, as shown by (181), the grammatical counterparts of (177) and (180):

(181)
a. [Gianni e Mario]i
mi hanno chiesto di ricevere almeno uno di loroi.
Gianni and Mario asked me to meet at least one of them
b. Maria deve essere innamorata di Gianni e Marioi perché vuole ricevere almeno uno di loroi prima delle undici.
Maria must be in love with Gianni and Mario because [she] wants to meet at least one of them before eleven

If so, binding-theoretic data cannot be used to argue against the DP analysis of ne. 35 Incidentally, note that these data support the proposal made above that ne is not the pronominal counterpart of the partitive PP.
Cinque (1991: n. 7) proposes the same as Belletti on the basis of the fact that ne can co-occur with a relative clause, while accusative and dative object clitics cannot.

(182)
a. Di libri, ne ho letti due di cui non ricordo ora il titolo.
of books NE have.1Sg read two of which [I] not remember now the title
b. *I libri di Gianni, li ho letti di cui non ricordo ora il titolo.
the books of Gianni them have.1Sg read of which not remember.1Sg now the title

Assuming that relative clauses are adjoined to DPs, Cinque explains the ungrammaticality of (182b) by proposing that accusative and dative object clitics are DPs, and that in the case of adjunctions, the biggest DP is pronominalized. The grammaticality of (182a) follows if quantitative ne is an NP (this assumption is independently necessary in Cinque's analysis since he takes quantified noun phrases to be DPs, not QPs).
There is a major objection to this reasoning. Ne can also pronominalize a noun phrase that contains a relative clause:

(183)
Di libri di cui non ricordo ora il titolo, ne ho letti due.
of books of which not remember.1Sg now the title, NE have.1Sg read two

The proposal that ne is an NP cannot account for (183); in this case it is presumably a DP. We would thus end up with two different analyses of quantitative ne: NP in (182a) and DP in (183). This has the disadvantage of attributing different categories to one and the same lexical item, as noticed in section 4.1 for the co-occurrence of ne with (apparent) arguments of the noun. Furthermore, in an anti-symmetric view of relative clauses, ne in (183) should correspond to the whole relative CP embedded under the quantifier, making the categorial status of ne even more problematic. Leaving open the question of the correct analysis of relative clauses, we conclude that these data cannot be used as counter-arguments to the hypothesis that quantitative ne is a DP.

subsection.heading: 4.4 Quantitative er in Dutch
subsection.p: In Dutch, quantitative er (184a) is homophonous to prepositional (184b), locative (184c), and expletive (184d) er (examples from Bennis 1986: section 3.2).

(184)
a. Ik heb er twee gekocht.
I have ER two bought
b. Ik heb met hem [er over] gesproken.
I have with him there about talked
c. Jan woont er
nog maar kort.
Jan lives there only briefly
d. Er kocht niemand een boek
there bought nobody a book

As for French en and Italian ne, the question arises as to whether quantitative er is to be analyzed as having the same categorial status as the other instances of er. 36 Van Riemsdijk (1978a: 197) observes that quantitative er differs from the prepositional er found in PPs such as (185) (from Van Riemsdijk 1978a: 87) in that it can never occur inside its own projection and does not have a [+WH] counterpart; see (186).

(185)
a. vlak er na
right there after
b. Waar heb je op gerekend?
where have you on counted?
‘What did you count on?’

(186)
a. *de verwoesting van er [drie e]
the destruction of ER three
‘the destruction of three of them’
b. *Waar heb je [drie e]?
where have you three?
‘Of what do you have three?’

Bennis (1986: 177) further points out that quantitative er differs from both prepositional and locative er in that it is not related to a paradigm of R-pronouns; see (187). Quantitative er cannot be replaced by other R-pronouns such as hier and daar.

(187)
a. *Ik heb hier
gisteren [twee e] gekocht.
I have here yesterday two bought
b. *Ik heb daar
haar [veel e] gegeven.
I have there to-her many given
Furthermore, quantitative er, as opposed to prepositional, locative, and expletive er, cannot occur in sentence-initial position (Bennis 1986: 177).

(188)
a. *Er zijn [twee e] verschenen.
ER are two appeared
b. *Er hebben enkele mensen haar [twee e] gegeven.
ER have some people to-her two given
These properties suggest that quantitative er is different from the other instances of er, which are presumably pro-PPs. 37

Blom (1977) analyzes quantitative er as an N′. This proposal is also adopted by Bennis (1977) and Van Riemsdijk (1978a). Quantitative er does not occur with the head noun (189a), nor with prenominal adjectives (189b). It does, however, occur with relative clauses and postnominal adjectives, see (190).

(189)
a. Ik heb (*er) drie boeken gekocht.
I have ER three books bought
b. Ik heb (*er) nog drie gele.
I have ER still three yellow
‘I still have three yellow ones.’

(190)
a. Ik heb er drie die vol zitten met luizen.
I have ER three that full sit with lice
‘I have three that are full of lice.’
b. Ik kocht er een/’n groot.
I bought ER one big

On a par with the material left stranded by ne-cliticization in Italian, relative clauses and postnominal adjectives, as in (190), can be analyzed as predicative modifiers of the noun. As pointed out in Cinque (1991: 123), the postnominal adjective in (190b) has the same non-agreeing form that is found with predicative adjectives, (191a), not the agreeing form found with prenominal adjectives, as in (191b) (cf. *Ik kocht er een/’n grote and (189b)).

(191)
a. De tafel is groot.
the table is big
b. Een/’n grote tafel
a big table

In line with the proposal made for French en and Italian ne, we take Dutch existential quantifiers to combine with a quantitative DP and a partitive PP. Er pronominalizes the DP complement of the quantifier.

As in Italian, Dutch er can co-occur with a partitive PP, as in (192a). However, the partitive PP cannot contain an overt noun, in which case only an empty category can occur. Compare (192b, c) with Italian (142). 38

(192)
a. Ik heb er twee gekocht, van degene die je me aangeraden had.
I have ER two bought of those that you to-me advised had
b. Ik heb (*er) [twee e
van deze boeken] gekocht.
I have ER two of these books bought
c. [Twee e
van die boeken] heb ik (*er) gisteren gekocht.
two of those books have I ER yesterday bought

The PP introduced by van can also be analyzed as an adjunct partitive PP (on a par with the PP introduced by tra or di in Italian, see (101), (102), (103)). It can be separated by the quantified noun phrase and appear in the Middlefield or in sentence-initial position, as in (193) (Bennis 1986: 199; 251, n. 8). In this case, er is obligatory, differently from (192b, c), which contains a true partitive PP:

(193)
a. Ik heb van die boeken *(er) gisteren [twee e] gekocht.
I have of those books ER yesterday two bought
b. Van deze boeken heb ik *(er) [twee e] gekocht.
of these books have I ER two bought

The adjunct partitive PP can also follow the quantified noun phrase. This is shown by the following sentence, where er can bind both the quantitative DP and the R-position inside the PP with van (Bennis 1986: 199).

(194)
Ik heb er gisteren [twee e] [t van] gekocht.
I have ER yesterday two of bought

Sentence (194) displays the phenomenon of haplology, i.e., the peculiar property that one surface realization of er can bind more than one syntactic position. Quantitative er can be combined with expletive, prepositional, and locative er; see (195). It can also bind the empty category of two quantified noun phrases, one in subject position and one in object position; see (196) (Bennis 1986: section 3.2.5).

(195)
a.
Expletive + quantitative
dat er niemand [twee e] gekocht heeft
that ER nobody two bought has
b.
Quantitative + prepositional
dat Jan er [twee e] [t over] gelezen heeft
that Jan ER two about read has
c.
Quantitative + locative
Jan zou drie weken van zijn vakantie in Italië doorbrengen.
Jan would three weeks of his holidays in Italy spend,
maar uiteindelijk heeft hij er maar [twee e] t
doorgebracht.
but eventually has he ER only two spent
d.
Expletive + quantitative + prepositional
dat er niemand [drie e] [t over] geschreven heeft
that ER nobody three about written has
e.
Expletive + quantitative + locative
dat er nog maar [twee e] t
woonden
that ER yet only two lived

(196)
dat er [twee e] [één e] gekocht hebben
that ER two one bought have

Although, as far as we know, it was never pointed out before, haplology is also marginally found in Italian, as shown by the following sentence: ne stands for both the quantitative clitic extracted from the postverbal subject, and the pleonastic clitic pronoun that obligatorily occurs with the idiomatic reflexive usage of the motion verb, namely andarsene (‘go away’).

(197)
Se ne sono andati via [molti t].
Refl NE are gone away many
‘Many of them went away.’

subsection.heading: 5 Conclusion
subsection.p: In this chapter we have analyzed quantified noun phrases and quantitative clitic pronouns. Our conclusions can be summarized as follows.

li.p: Expressions of quantity can be realized by different lexical categories, only one of which we label Q. We have also found quantity adjectives, which behave as a separate class of modifiers of the noun. It is likely that other categories can also express quantity (e.g., Ns, although this has not been investigated here).
Qs are external to the DP contained in the quantified expression. Qs are heads that project their own maximal projection, QP.

Different classes of Qs have been identified which combine with different phrases. Existential Qs combine with a quantitative DP, which checks partitive case, and a partitive PP. Distributive Qs combine with a quantitative DP, which checks partitive case, a partitive PP, and a distributive operator (OP). Universal Qs combine with a definite DP.
These properties can be conceived of as selectional properties of quantifers. If Qs have selectional properties, they can been analyzed as lexical heads.

The partitive PP selected by existential and distributive Qs must be distinguished from ‘adjunct’ partitive PPs, which can co-occur with any type of noun phrase, and from ‘qualitative’ PPs, which are NP adjuncts and can also co-occur with any type of noun phrase (see n.13).
Quantitative clitics bind a maximal, not an intermediate, projection. This projection is the quantitative DP.

subsection.heading: NOTES
subsection.p: This chapter has been conceived as a work for four hands from beginning to end. However, for every legal requirement Giuliana Giusti is responsible for sections 1–3.1 and Anna Cardinaletti is responsible for sections 3.2–4. We are indebted to Roberto Zamparelli for comments and constructive criticism on a preliminary version of the chapter.

p.span: 1 On the grammar of partitive constructions of this type, see Kayne (1994), Corver (1998), Den Dikken (1998a), Vos (1999), and the references quoted there.
2 Postverbal subjects of unaccusative verbs behave like objects, as expected.

subsection.p:
With postverbal subjects of transitive and intransitive verbs, neither ne nor PRO is possible, the former because it is governed by the verb, the latter because of a violation of subjacency.
(ii) a. Hanno parlato tre ragazze.
have spoken three girls
b. *Ne hanno parlato tre.
c. *Hanno parlato tre [e].
In PPs, ne is ungrammatical, and the null category is very marginal:
Example (iiib) represents a violation of subjacency; PRO in (iiic) is marginally accepted due to the non-governing nature of the preposition. We refer to Belletti and Rizzi (1981) for details.

p.span: 3 This generalization is only apparently contradicted by the English gloss. See section 3.1 for discussion.

4 Example (63) shows that number agreement between the quantifier and the DP can be suspended, depending on the selectional properties of the quantifier (cf. section 3.3.2 for the agreement properties of quantifiers and their complement). Cf. Quirk, et al. (1985: 759) where it is noticed that in this case the predicate is singular, as in many a member has protested against the proposal. When the NP is a coordinate structure, both singular and plural agreement give marginal results (1985: 959) ?many a boy and girl is/are left homeless.
5 The structure in (65b) can also capture the Ladin data brought about in (92).
6 The data in (69) can be reproduced in many European languages, for example in Italian. Notice that (ib) is perfectly acceptable, while its counterpart (69b) is marginal for some English speakers:

row.entry: I molti/tre/parecchi/*gli alcuni studenti che conosco sono tutti pigri.
Gli studenti che conosco sono molti/tre/parecchi/*alcuni.

p.span: 7 They do not display the -n ending, as shown here for beide:

subsection.p: The lack of a determiner following the quantifier beide in (ia) is explained by Giusti (1993: 103) as follows. The determiner incorporates into the quantifier and thereby triggers the determiner-like morphology on the quantifier. The covert presence of the determiner in (ia) is supported by the fact that when the DP is extracted out of the quantifier, as in (iia), the determiner must be overt:
It is reasonable to extend the same analysis to English (ib) and (iib).

p.span: 8 Also see the discussion of (95).
9 Cf. Giusti (1991b, 1993, 1995) for a detailed discussion.

10 In considering the following Romanian examples, one must keep in mind that the enclitic article in Romanian appears on the leftmost lexical head in the DP; see Grosu (1988) and Giusti (1993), among others.

11 Zamparelli is not clear whether the weak–strong distinction is obtained through different merging points, through movement from PD to SD, or whether the two options are both possible and, in this case, what would make either choice operative in different cases.

12 Take, as an example, a diadic verb such as scrivere (‘write’) in (i). Even when the internal argument is not projected, it is understood as an undetermined object. The same is true for the goal argument of a diadic verb such as regalare (‘give a present’) in (ii).

row.entry: ‘I gave a book as a present.’

p.span: 13 R. Zamparelli (p.c.) points out that definite and universally quantified DPs can sometimes co-occur with a PP introduced by di, as in (i), on a par with quantified DPs, as shown in (ii):

row.entry: of those that can be read quickly
‘I like the books that can be read quickly.’
of those that can be read quickly

subsection.p: The PP introduced by di in (i) and (ii) differs, however, from the PP introduced by the same preposition in (100a). In (i), the di-PP does not get a partitive, but a ‘qualitative’ interpretation. Example (i) can be paraphrased as Mi piacciono (tutti) i libri del tipo che si legge velocemente, ‘I like (all) the books of the type that can be read quickly’. This PP can be analyzed as a modifier of the noun libri, unrelated to the QP.

There are other empirical reasons to believe this. The ‘qualitative’ PP is compatible with any type of DP. Furthermore, the ‘qualitative’ PP cannot be left-dislocated on its own, but only together with the DP:

row.entry: *[Di quelli che si leggono velocemente] ne ho comprati dieci.
of those that can be read quickly NE have.1Sg bought ten
Libri di quelli che si leggono velocemente ne ho comprati dieci.
books of those that can be read quickly NE have.1Sg bought ten

subsection.p: In this respect, it crucially differs from the adjunct partitive PP in (102).

This ‘qualitative’ PP, which contains a kind-denoting plural, is also found in the English expression many of them in contexts like (iv) (from Cresti 2003: 83), and differs from the partitive PP in the homophonous many of them in contexts like (v).
(iv) Late homework assignments are impossible to grade, and there are many of them.
(v) I bought a hundred books, and I have read many of them.
Cresti (2003: n. 11) points out another possible reading of English many of them where of them has the same interpretation as Italian quantitative ne:
(vi) John has few friends, but Mary has many of them.

We take the last instance of of them as the pronominal version of the quantitative DP, in which the preposition of realizes partitive case (see section 3.3.1). This appears not to be possible in Italian, which only realizes Partitive case with the preposition di when the quantifier is not overt or in a non-local relation with its complement (see section 3.3.3).

p.span: 14 The sentence in (i) with ne is also ungrammatical. Ne cannot be extracted from a postverbal subject (see section 2.2):
15 But, of course, (113b) can be felicitous in a context in which human beings make nests, for example, in order to attract migrating birds into their gardens.

16 The distributive operator OP could be merged as the third argument of the Q in a ‘QP-shell’ lower in the structure and later merged to [Spec, FP] to get scope over the rest of the quantified phrase.
17 Universal quantifiers must be assumed to be transparent and to transmit the case assigned to their projection.
18 This proposal has been previously made by Pesetsky (1982).
19 Examples (129) and (130) are both taken from Enç (1991: 6).

20 The cases in which the preposition di is absent, as in (i), must be analyzed as Hanging Topic constructions, where the hanging topic, which occurs in first position on the left-edge of the sentence, is marked nominative by default (Cinque 1990c):

subsection.p: In cases in which the peripheral DP cannot be analyzed as a Hanging Topic, di is obligatory. This is the case in (134b) since there is no Hanging Topic on the right-edge of the sentence, and in (ii), where the quantitative DP is embedded and therefore can only be analyzed as left-dislocated.

p.span: 21 The definiteness requirement of the PP is known in the literature as the ‘Partitive constraint’ (see Ladusaw 1982; Wilkinson 1991a; Hoeksema 1996; Barker 1998; de Hoop 1997, among others, for discussion). In our framework, this semantic property can be encoded in the argument structure of (existential and distributive) quantifiers.
22 This co-indexing should be kept distinct from Binding, since Binding applies to full DPs and rules their referential interpretation.

23 The phrase embedded in the partitive PP can contain a lexical NP, preceded by a determiner or a demonstrative, as in (137), or can contain a pronoun (a pronominal demonstrative or a personal pronoun), as in (i):

subsection.p: In this case, the content of the lexical NP is recovered from the context.

p.span: 24 Our analysis of (141d) differs from Belletti's (1979: 1559), according to which di cui is left-dislocated and resumed by ne.

25 In Italian, it is always possible to left- or right-dislocate a PP, with no resumptive pronoun, cf. Cinque (1990c: chapter 2) for the distribution of resumptive clitics in left-dislocation constructions.

26 The following sentences, where each and ciascuno combine with a definite plural DP in subject position, should not be analyzed as ‘floating’ structures, but as containing a small clause whose subject is controlled by the definite plural DP and quantified by the quantifier (cf. Sportiche 1988: 440).

27 Belletti and Rizzi (1996b) assume that agreement takes place in the specifier of QP. Given the more elaborated structure proposed in (122) above, it is natural to assume that agreement takes place in [Spec, AgrQP].

28 Parallel to Campbell's (1996b) proposal to analyze [Spec, DP] as the locus relevant for interpretation, we propose here that the [Spec, FP] projected by Q is where the semantics of the quantified noun phrases is processed at LF.
29 For previous analyses of French en, see, among others, Kayne (1975), Haïk (1982), and Pollock (1986).

30 Sentence (167c) can be marginally acceptable for those speakers who can reinterpret the infinitival introduced by di as a purpose clause usually introduced by per, as shown in (ia). This possibility also arises with the overt noun in (167a), as shown in (ib):

subsection.p: The occurrence of the prepositional complementizer per guarantees that the infinitival clause is not a complement of the noun modo, since in Italian this preposition introduces a purpose (infinitival) clause.

p.span: 31 En triggers past participle agreement in some French varieties (Grevisse 1986: section 910).
32 In a framework that allows deletion operations, Kayne assumes that the preposition de is deleted in order to get the grammatical deux sœurs.

33 Milner (1978b: 138) notes for French that left- and right-dislocation behave differently in this respect. Agreement in number is required in right-dislocation. His data can be reproduced in Italian.

row.entry: of horse/horses, I NE have one
of horse/horses, I NE have two
I NE have one, of horse/horses
I NE have two, of horse/horses

p.span: 34 For similar binding facts of French en, see Ruwet (1990) and Lamiroy (1991a, b).
35 As observed by Lamiroy (1991a: 411, n. 6) and (1991b: 43), French en does not show any anti-reflexive effect.

row.entry: ‘This/a man is worth any other man.’

subsection.p: She concludes that en does not enter coreference relationships and is exempted from the Binding Theory.

p.span: 36 Bennis (1986: 251, n. 10) notes that “all proposals concerning quantitative er explicitely or implicitely consider quantitative er to be homonymous with the weak form of the R-paradigm which we find with prepositional and locative er.” However, “historically, quantitative er developed from a different source, a genitive form of the third person singular, iro.”

37 The fact that quantitative er cannot occur in specifier positions (PP-internally, (186a), and in sentence-initial position, (188)) might suggest that it differs from the other instances of er, not only in categorial status but in another respect as well. Since specifier positions are excluded to clitic pronouns (Cardinaletti and Starke 1999), quantitative er can be taken to be a clitic pronoun, while the other instances of er can be weak pronouns.
38 In contrast with Italian, Dutch allows for an empty category to co-occur with a prenominal agreeing adjective, in which case er is ungrammatical. See (189b) and (i):

subsection.p: Examples (189b) and (i) are possible because Dutch is similar to other Germanic languages in allowing an empty NP inside the quantified noun phrase even if it is not resumed by a quantitative clitic. Compare (i) with the parallel German example in (ii).
